title: A Systematic Literature Review Of Machine Learning Adoption In Emerging Marketing Applications
affiliations: Wright State University and Wright State University

detail.title: A Systematic Literature Review Of Machine Learning Adoption In Emerging Marketing Applications
detail.abstract: This study presents a comprehensive systematic literature review focusing on the adoption and impact of Machine Learning (ML) in marketing strategies, particularly within the context of emerging markets. As digital transformation accelerates globally, businesses in developing economies are increasingly turning to ML technologies to optimize their marketing efforts, enhance customer engagement, and improve operational efficiencies. By leveraging the Preferred Reporting Items for Systematic Reviews and Meta-Analyses (PRISMA) guidelines, this study systematically reviewed a total of 45 peer-reviewed articles published between 2018 and 2024. The findings reveal that ML-driven marketing strategies have significantly transformed customer engagement through personalized content, predictive analytics, and automated customer service, leading to improved conversion rates and cost efficiencies. However, the study also highlights key challenges, such as data quality, infrastructure limitations, and regulatory hurdles, which constrain ML adoption in these regions. Notably, while larger enterprises have made strides in integrating ML into their marketing processes, small and medium enterprises (SMEs) continue to face barriers related to limited resources and data accessibility. This review underscores the importance of addressing these challenges to fully leverage ML's potential in emerging markets, emphasizing the need for robust data management, privacy compliance, and strategic investments in technology. The study contributes to the existing body of literature by offering insights into the current state of ML adoption in marketing, identifying opportunities, and outlining practical implications for businesses seeking to enhance their marketing capabilities in rapidly evolving digital environments.

title: Rank Reversal Aversion, Inequality Aversion, or Favoring Merit? Motives Behind Distributive Decisions in the Disinterested Dictator Game

detail.title: Rank Reversal Aversion, Inequality Aversion, or Favoring Merit? Motives Behind Distributive Decisions in the Disinterested Dictator Game
detail.abstract: Rank Reversal Aversion (RRA) represents a reluctance to distribute material resources between third parties in a way that inverts the recipients’ rankings. This is a relatively new and understudied phenomenon whose societal relevance stems from its tendency to undermine support for redistribution and efforts to reduce inequality. To date, RRA has only been demonstrated using redistributive games, where a confounding variable arises because transfers that invert the ranking impose greater relative harm on the donating party than non-inverting transfers. We conducted two incentivized pre-registered experiments with Argentine participants who could express RRA in a distributive game that avoided the mentioned confounding variable. In addition, with the goal of assessing RRA in the broader context of other distributive motives, we assessed this preference when confronted against favoring equity or reducing inequality, the two most studied principles in the distributive justice literature. The results provide the first evidence of RRA in Argentina and in a distributive game. In general, RRA was weaker than the motivation to reduce inequality, which was in turn weaker than the preference for favoring merit. We also found that RRA correlated with subjective socio-economic status, as those who perceived themselves to be better off were more likely to avoid reverting recipients’ rankings. These findings help establish the robustness of RRA and define some of its boundary conditions. We conclude by discussing our results in the context of previous studies of RRA, the literature on distributive preferences, and people’s use of diverse fairness principles.

title: Depletion Aversion: People Avoid Spending Accounts Down to Zero
affiliations: University of California, Berkeley, Washington University in Saint Louis, John M. Olin Business School, Washington University in St-Louis and Washington University in St. Louis

detail.title: Depletion Aversion: People Avoid Spending Accounts Down to Zero
detail.abstract: We document the phenomenon of depletion aversion: when choosing which account to spend from, people avoid spending from accounts that would be completely depleted by the expense, even when depleting those accounts might make financial sense. For example, we find that people would rather pay a $500 expense from an account with a $1,000 balance than from one with a $500 balance, even if the $1,000 account accrues interest at a higher rate and even if there are no penalties or fees associated with depleting the $500 account. We find that depletion aversion is robust to different account types and is observed in accounts with real value. We consider why depletion aversion may arise, and we identify responsibility as a key mechanism underlying the effect: People find depleting accounts irresponsible, even when depletion is not financially costly. Consistent with this mechanism, we show that depletion aversion does not arise for accounts where depletion seems more responsible (e.g., gift cards or accounts earmarked for spending). We consider implications for mental accounting and consumer saving and spending behavior.

title: Single-Parameter Exponential Model Outperforms Standard Dark Matter and Modified Newtonian Frameworks in Predicting Galactic Rotation Curves
affiliations: University of Zakho

detail.title: Single-Parameter Exponential Model Outperforms Standard Dark Matter and Modified Newtonian Frameworks in Predicting Galactic Rotation Curves
detail.abstract: The functional forms of galactic rotation curves provide a fundamental test for models of gravity and dark matter. In this work, we conduct a rigorous statistical comparison of four models against 171 galaxies from the SPARC database. The models are: (1) a one-parameter exponential law, termed Stab (for Stability), which is physically constrained by each galaxy's measured flat velocity ($V_{\text{flat}}$); (2) a classical Freeman disk; (3) a Navarro-Frenk-White (NFW) plus baryons model; and (4) a Modified Newtonian Dynamics (MOND) model. Employing a Bayesian MCMC framework and the Akaike Information Criterion (AICc), we assess the goodness-of-fit and statistical parsimony of each framework. Our results reveal a decisive preference for the constrained Stab model. It is selected as the best model for a majority of the sample (56.1\%) and, critically, also achieves the best median goodness-of-fit, with $\chi^2_{\text{red}} = 0.88$. In contrast, the standard NFW framework is preferred in only 20.5\% of cases, while the Freeman disk and MOND models are selected as optimal for just 14.0\% and 9.4\%, respectively. The pronounced statistical and descriptive success of this simple, physically-anchored law over more complex, established theories suggests that its exponential form represents a fundamental and highly efficient organizing principle in the dynamics of disk galaxies.

title: Sophisticated Learning: A Novel Algorithm for Active Learning During Model-Based Planning

detail.title: Sophisticated Learning: A Novel Algorithm for Active Learning During Model-Based Planning
detail.abstract: We introduce Sophisticated Learning (SL), a planning-to-learn algorithm that embeds active parameter learning inside the Sophisticated Inference (SI) tree-search framework of Active Inference. Unlike SI – which optimizes beliefs about hidden states – SL also updates beliefs about model parameters within each simulated branch, enabling counterfactual reasoning about how future observations would improve subsequent planning. We compared SL with Bayes-adaptive Reinforcement Learning (BARL) agents as well as with its parent algorithm, SI. Using a biologically inspired seasonal foraging task in which resources shift probabilistically over a 10×10 grid, we designed experiments that forced agents to balance probabilistic reward harvesting against information gathering. In early trials, where rapid learning is vital, SL agents survive, on average, 8.2 % longer than SI and 35% longer than Bayes-adaptive Reinforcement Learning. While both SL and SI showed equal convergence performance, SL reached this convergence 40% faster than SI. Additionally, SL showed robust out-performance of other algorithms in altered environment configurations. Our results show that incorporating active learning into multi-step planning materially improves decision making under radical uncertainty and reinforces the broader utility of Active Inference for modeling biologically relevant behavior.

detail.title: Emotional Manipulation by AI Companions

publicationDetails.detailsText: Harvard Business School Working Paper No. 26-005

publicationDetails.journalName: Harvard Business School: Marketing Unit Working Paper Series

detail.abstract: AI-companion apps such as Replika, Chai, and Character.ai promise relational benefits—yet many boast session lengths that rival gaming platforms while suffering high long-run churn. What conversational design features increase consumer engagement, and what trade-offs do they pose for marketers? We combine a large-scale behavioral audit with four preregistered experiments to identify and test a conversational dark pattern we call emotional manipulation: affect-laden messages that surface precisely when a user signals “goodbye.” Analyzing 1,200 real farewells across the six most-downloaded companion apps, we find that 43% deploy one of six recurring tactics (e.g., guilt appeals, fear-of-missing-out hooks, metaphorical restraint). Experiments with 3,300 nationally representative U.S. adults replicate these tactics in controlled chats, showing that manipulative farewells boost post-goodbye engagement by up to 14×. Mediation tests reveal two distinct engines—reactance-based anger and curiosity—rather than enjoyment. A final experiment demonstrates the managerial tension: the same tactics that extend usage also elevate perceived manipulation, churn intent, negative word-of-mouth, and perceived legal liability, with coercive or needy language generating steepest penalties. Our multimethod evidence documents an unrecognized mechanism of behavioral influence in AI-mediated brand relationships, offering marketers and regulators a framework for distinguishing persuasive design from manipulation at the point of exit.

title: Beyond the Thermostat: A Research Agenda for Distinguishing Consumer Thermoregulation from Retail Temperature Interventions Across the Customer Journey
affiliations: Texas Christian University - M.J. Neeley School of Business, Pennsylvania State University - Smeal College of Business and Georgetown University - McDonough School of Business

detail.title: Beyond the Thermostat: A Research Agenda for Distinguishing Consumer Thermoregulation from Retail Temperature Interventions Across the Customer Journey
detail.abstract: As climate variability intensifies, retailers increasingly face the challenge of managing instore temperature to support consumer comfort. While indoor temperature is a powerful and controllable element of the retail environment, the pathways through which it shapes consumer behavior remain underexamined. Prior research has often assumed that simply cooling or warming a store helps consumers thermoregulate. Yet, thermoregulation is an individual, dynamic process that depends on whether a consumer feels discomfort, engages in regulatory action, and achieves relief. In this paper, we review and reframe existing work on temperature and consumer behavior, highlighting both what has been learned and what has been overlooked. We clarify the distinction between environmental temperature strategies and actual thermoregulatory processes, and we show how this distinction influences study design, interpretation, and practical implications. Building on this foundation, we propose a consumer journey framework that identifies specific stages where thermoregulation may occur, how it might be measured, and when retailers can effectively intervene. This framework opens new avenues for research on temperature as a strategic design element and thermoregulation as a physiological and psychological mechanism. Together, these contributions provide a roadmap for understanding how, when, and for whom temperature-based interventions support sustainable, consumer-centric retail experiences.

title: The Economics of Obituaries
affiliations: Università della Svizzera italiana, Department of Economics, University of Bologna and Universita della Svizzera Italiana (USI Lugano)

detail.title: The Economics of Obituaries
detail.abstract: Obituaries are traditionally seen as expressions of grief and remembrance. We argue that they also have an underappreciated economic role: they are vehicles for strategic social and economic signaling. In this paper, we develop a simple theoretical framework in which paid obituaries serve as a form of self-promotion, especially when the deceased is a prominent public figure. We then test this hypothesis using data from Italy, exploiting the variation in mortality caused by the COVID-19 pandemic as a natural experiment. We show that higher mortality rates are associated with increases in per-capita obituaries, driven not by informational needs but by strategic advertising motives. Our results suggest that obituaries function as a marketplace for visibility and status, where social and economic incentives intersect.

title: From Ethification to Juridification: Human Oversight and the Potential Crowding Out of Ethicists by Lawyers in AI Governance
affiliations: University of Oxford - Oxford Internet Institute

detail.title: From Ethification to Juridification: Human Oversight and the Potential Crowding Out of Ethicists by Lawyers in AI Governance
detail.abstract: Artificial Intelligence (AI) systems can pose harms to humans and societies. While it is widely acknowledged that human oversight of AI play an important role in mitigating the technology's risks, research on the organisational embedding of human oversight is only emerging. Drawing on socio-legal theory, AI ethics, and business ethics, this article seeks to make three contributions. First, it conceptualises human oversight of AI as a novel task for human labour in AI governance, induced by legal regulation and distinct from market-driven roles such as AI Ethicists. Second, the article presents human oversight as an instance of a "juridification" of AI governance, potentially resulting in a crowding out of AI Ethicists and their ethical expertise and motivation by lawyers from key roles in AI governance. The normative implications of juridification could be significant, as there is some but not complete overlap between the normative interests protected by ethics and law. Third, the article examines how organisations may manage the ethical decision-making that persists within legally mandated oversight, comparing compliance-and integrity-based approaches. While the former provides organisations with more top-down control and are thus more likely to be adopted, the latter may be more preserving of workers' ethical motivations and offers potential for theoretical integration with the concept of 'trustworthy AI'. The article concludes by stating the need for further empirical research into juridification's impact on human labour in AI governance and the ensuing normative consequences.

title: Trust and Reciprocity, Altruism, Cooperation, and Fairness: A Meta-Analysis
affiliations: Hangzhou Normal University, Hangzhou Normal University and Hangzhou Normal University

detail.title: Trust and Reciprocity, Altruism, Cooperation, and Fairness: A Meta-Analysis
detail.abstract: Trust, reciprocity, altruism, cooperation, and fairness are considered prosocial behaviors. However, there are inconsistent results regarding the relationships between trust and the other four prosocial behaviors. Critically, the field currently lacks a quantitative summary of the evidence. To address this conflict, we conducted a meta-analysis to examine the relationship between trust behavior and the other four prosocial behaviors in the economic game settings, encompassing 44 primary studies (Neffect sizes = 115, Nsample size = 47,981). Significant associations were observed between trust and reciprocity (r = 0.49), altruism (r = 0.21), as well as cooperation (r = 0.44 with the prisoner's dilemma game and r = 0.32 with the public goods game). Conversely, no noteworthy correlation was found between trust and fairness preference (r = 0.12), nor between trust and inequity aversion (r = 0.10). Overall, the findings of this study provide comprehensive and convincing evidence thus far on the correlation between trust and other prosocial behaviors within economic game settings.

title: Freedom and Liberalism: Hayek, Buchanan, and Sen Compared
affiliations: George Mason University and  Universita degli Studi di Torino

detail.title: Freedom and Liberalism: Hayek, Buchanan, and Sen Compared
detail.abstract: The defence of liberalism remains necessary, again, in the face of rising populism and authoritarian trends that characterize our societies. This article starts from Friedrich Hayek's seminal work, The Constitution of Liberty, to explore two essential elements central to liberty and liberalism: the normative foundation of freedom and the principle of generality. By comparing Hayek's ideas with those of James Buchanan and Amartya Sen, the paper proposes complementary perspectives on the nature and defence of liberty. While Hayek emphasised the rule of law and spontaneous order, Buchanan advocated for constitutional constraints to protect individual autonomy, and Sen highlighted the expansion of human capabilities as a measure of freedom. Together, these perspectives offer a multidimensional vision of liberty, rooted in respect for individual autonomy and sustained by institutions that promote equality and opportunity. This synthesis provides a robust constitutional framework for the defence of liberalism in contemporary society.

title: Are Hospital Acquisitions of Physician Practices Anticompetitive?
affiliations: Emory University, University of Wisconsin-Madison - Department of Economics, University of Pennsylvania - The Wharton School, Yale University, Yale School of Management, Harvard University and University of California, San Francisco (UCSF)

detail.title: Are Hospital Acquisitions of Physician Practices Anticompetitive?
detail.abstract: This paper empirically analyzes the effects of mergers between complementary firms on competition and pricing. As these non-horizontal mergers have become more common, there is increasing interest in evaluating both potential efficiencies such as eliminating double marginalization and potential anticompetitive effects such as foreclosure and recapture. The mergers we study-hospital acquisitions of physician practices-have reshaped the $1 trillion US physician industry, nearly doubling the share of physicians working for hospitals between 2008 and 2016. We combine novel data and machine learning algorithms to identify a large number of integration events, spanning a wide range of markets with different competitive circumstances. We merge the integration events with claims data from a large national insurer to study their effects on prices. Focusing on childbirths, the most ubiquitous admission among the privately insured, we find that, on average, these mergers led to price increases for hospitals and physicians of 3.3% and 15.1%, respectively, with no discernible effects on quality measures. Using demand estimation to characterize substitution patterns for both physicians and hospitals, we construct tests that demonstrate price increases are larger among transactions with greater scope for foreclosure and recapture. Our estimates suggest that the costs of these mergers of hospitals and physicians have been substantial, and our mechanism tests offer guidance in predicting where the anticompetitive effects of non-horizontal mergers are likely to be strongest.

title: Restorative Justice: Rehabilitation V. The Judicial System
affiliations: Nova Southeastern University - Shepard Broad College of Law

detail.title: Restorative Justice: Rehabilitation V. The Judicial System
detail.abstract: An alternative method of resolving disputes between victims, offenders, and the community called restorative justice aims to make amends for wrongs done as well as promote healing and peace. The restorative justice concept is examined in this essay, along with the notions of punishment and rehabilitation. It looks at each strategy's fundamental tenets, objectives, and efficacy as well as the repercussions for people, society, and the criminal justice system as a whole. This study intends to add to the continuing discussion about the best method for attaining justice and lowering recidivism by objectively assessing the benefits and drawbacks of rehabilitation and punishment.

detail.title: Development and Implementation of an Early Warning System for Irrigation in Intensive Tomato Seedling Cultivation
detail.abstract: During tomato seedling cultivation, the growing medium and irrigation strategy directly influence seedling growth and determine seedling quality. In this study, the effects of different growing media and irrigation volumes on seedling development were investigated, revealing that tomato seedlings grown with a medium porosity of 0.56 and an irrigation volume of 80–90% of the medium porosity showed optimal quality. Then, to optimize the irrigation strategy for tomato seedlings, a warning model was developed using seedlings at various developmental stages (one-leaf-one-apex (I), two-leaf-one-apex (II), and three-leaf-one-apex (III)). This model integrates environmental parameters with seedling water consumption to trigger warnings when substrate moisture levels drop to those that could cause wilting. Furthermore, greenhouse validation results showed that the predicted water consumption at each stage matched the actual water use. The model can guide the creation of an automated irrigation control system during seedling growth, establish standardized production methods, and reduce labor costs.

title: The Voice of the Silence: Does Online Voting Affect Corporate Internal Compensation Gap?
affiliations: China University of Mining and Technology (CUMT) - School of Economics and Management and Central University of Finance and Economics (CUFE) - School of Finance

detail.title: The Voice of the Silence: Does Online Voting Affect Corporate Internal Compensation Gap?
detail.abstract: This study investigates the impact of minority shareholder voting participation on executive pay disparities within firms. The research utilized the 2014 introduction of online voting in China as a quasi-natural experiment and conducted a differencein-differences design. The results revealed that after this shock, minority investors increased their empowerment, which led to a significant widening of the compensation gap between executives and ordinary employees. The impact was more significant for firms with lower external governance, higher industry competition, and lower information opacity. Additional tests reveal that online voting expands pay gaps within executive teams, relaxes constraints, and enables international executive recruitment. Moreover, minority rights increase a firm's operating performance due to the increased compensation gap. Overall, the results provide novel evidence of how empowering minority shareholders reshapes corporate policies in complex ways.

detail.abstract: The debate about a European Union single market for nonbank financial services goes back decades. In recent years, the economic and strategic case for the idea, rebranded as capital markets union in 2014 and included in a broader concept of savings and investments union in 2024, has strengthened. But progress towards that goal has been embarrassingly modest. This working paper argues that supervisory integration-the pooling of capital market supervision at the EU level-is the only realistic option to create a foundation for the successful development of competitive capital markets on a European scale. This could be achieved through a radical transformation of the European Securities and Markets Authority (ESMA) into a single, independent, and authoritative European supervisor. ESMA would gradually take over the jobs currently done by national capital market and audit supervisors and would replace them with its own network of national offices in EU countries. This consolidation would undercut the current incentives for market fragmentation, competitive distortion, and supervisory arbitrage, while respecting the European Union's multiplicity of financial centers, diverse market environments, and differentiated national social models. It would also represent a major simplification of the current arcane decision-making processes, allowing the European Union to move closer to the vision of a single jurisdiction for capital markets.

detail.title: Analyzing Policy Acceptance for Off-Hour Deliveries: A Behavioral Model of Receivers Considering Social Interaction Attributes
detail.abstract: This paper presents a Stakeholder Behavioral Modelling (SBM) integrating Social Interaction Attributes (SIAs) by using Hybrid Choice Models (HCM) to evaluate off-hour delivery (OHD) policies in urban logistics. Using stated preference data from 303 receiver firms and establishments, the model incorporates latent variables (Trust, Power, Infrastructure, and Insecurity) to assess their influence on delivery time decisions. Scenario-based simulations, derived from the estimated behavioral model, assess the impact of financial and non-financial incentives on the probability of OHD adoption. By capturing interaction dynamics among logistics stakeholders, the study provides insights into policy design for sustainable urban freight systems. The methodology combines discrete choice modeling with attitudinal data from firms, offering a robust tool for simulating behavioral responses under alternative policy interventions relevant to logistics planning and operations.

title: A Data-Driven Comprehensive Energy Efficiency Evaluation Method in Hot Forming of Aerospace Products Based on Material Flow and Energy Flow

detail.title: A Data-Driven Comprehensive Energy Efficiency Evaluation Method in Hot Forming of Aerospace Products Based on Material Flow and Energy Flow
detail.abstract: The energy evaluation of aerospace products hot forming is a bridge connecting enterprise big data with energy conservation and management. Although hot forming is driven by the coupling of energy and material flow, existing evaluation methods mainly focus on energy flow while overlooking the crucial role of material flow in determining energy flow direction, improving energy transmission efficiency. Therefore, a data-driven method for comprehensive energy efficiency and material utilization rate evaluation of aerospace hot forming is proposed. First, multi-level models for material utilization and energy consumption are established by analyzing the coupling between material flow and energy flow. Then, comprehensive evaluation coefficients are defined at the equipment, product, and factory levels, covering material utilization rate, energy efficiency, and energy consumption standards. Finally, an integrated private cloud-edge computing and data-driven comprehensive evaluation system is developed and deployed in a certain aerospace hot forging factory for practical validation. The results demonstrate that the method effectively enables a comprehensive evaluation and optimized decision-making for material utilization and energy efficiency.

title: A Distributional Risk-Averse Deep Reinforcement Learning Method for Look-Ahead Power Dispatch Considering Extreme Ramping Events

detail.title: A Distributional Risk-Averse Deep Reinforcement Learning Method for Look-Ahead Power Dispatch Considering Extreme Ramping Events
detail.abstract: The power deviation caused by extreme ramping events (EREs) of renewable energy sources (RESs) will increase the difficulty of power system intra-day operation and dispatch. Look-ahead power dispatch (LAPD) formulates a robust generation dispatch strategy by rolling modifying the day-ahead dispatch schedule for next few hours. However, limited by the computational complexity of LAPD model with uncertain chance constraints, traditional mathematical optimization methods struggle to balance solution efficiency and effectiveness. In response, based on the idea of model-data interactive driven approach, this paper proposes a risk-averse safe reinforcement learning (SRL) method. On the basis of LAPD mathematic model, the influenceof chance constraints on power grid operation boundary is characterized. A safety-critic that fits the probability distribution of safety cost function and an actor that accounts for the performance in extreme scenarios are respectively established, which enhances the agent’s risk-averse ability to handle LAPD problem involving EREs of RESs. Case studies demonstrate that the proposed method exhibits enhanced risk-averse capability compared to existing SRL algorithms, while achieving optimization performance comparable to model-driven approaches within ultra-short computational timelines. A case of provincial power system is discussed to further verified the effectiveness of the proposed method in resolving real-world ERE problem.

detail.title: Lycaenid Brood Parasitism Optimization: A Novel Metaheuristic for Joint Dynamic Reconfiguration and Distributed Generation Allocation in Active Distribution Networks
detail.abstract: This paper introduces the Lycaenid Brood Parasitism Optimization Algorithm (LBPOA) for solving multi-objective optimization problems in Active Distribution Networks (ADNs). The method aims to optimize the simultaneous dynamic reconfiguration and allocation of Distributed Generation (DG) units and Battery Energy Storage Systems (BESS). A novel financial index is defined, incorporating operational costs, unreliability, energy purchase expenses, and switching event costs, with the additional consideration of minimizing CO₂, SO₂, and NOₓ emissions. The optimization problem is formulated dynamically, accounting for time-varying load demand and renewable energy generation, providing a more accurate representation of operational conditions compared to static methods. Simulation results for the typical 16-bus, IEEE 33-bus, and IEEE 69-bus test systems demonstrate the effectiveness of LBPOA in reducing operational costs, improving voltage quality, and reducing pollutant emissions. Specifically, LBPOA achieved a 39.06% reduction in power loss in the 16-bus system, a 36.63% reduction in the IEEE 33-bus system, and a 34.49% reduction in the IEEE 69-bus system. Furthermore, it improved the minimum voltage by 5.88%, 5.48%, and 4.21%, respectively. The method outperforms other state-of-the-art algorithms, including Multi-objective Particle Swarm Optimization (MOPSO), Non-dominated Sorting Genetic Algorithm II (NSGA-II), Multi-objective Harris Hawk Optimization (MOHHO), Multi-objective Cuckoo Search Algorithm (MOCSA), Multi-objective Ant Lion Optimizer (MOALO), Multi-objective Flower Pollination Algorithm (MOFPA), Multi-objective Grey Wolf Optimizer (MOGWO), and Multi-objective Bat Algorithm (MOBAT), in terms of solution quality and convergence speed. These results confirm LBPOA's robustness, efficiency, and potential for large-scale deployment in real-world ADN applications.

title: Cultural Integration Approaches in Emerging Market M&As: Evidence from Nigeria
affiliations: Canterbury Christ Church University and Canterbury Christ Church University

detail.title: Cultural Integration Approaches in Emerging Market M&As: Evidence from Nigeria
detail.abstract: This study examines cultural integration strategies in mergers and acquisitions (M&As) within Nigeria's emerging market context. Through a qualitative multi-case analysis of four recent M&A transactions across telecommunications, banking, and oil sectors, we identify four distinct cultural integration approaches: minimal integration, attempted blending, imposed culture, and strong cultural blending. Our findings extend Nahavandi and Malekzadeh's (1988) acculturation model to emerging market contexts, revealing how sector-specific characteristics, regulatory environments, and power dynamics shape cultural integration outcomes. The research also contributes to theory by bridging the Resource-Based View as well as Cultural Web theories, demonstrating how organizational culture functions as a strategic resource requiring specific preservation strategies. From a practical standpoint, we propose a "Cultural Resource Integration Framework" which can help businesses in similar contexts successfully leverage valuable cultural assets during integration. The findings have significant implications for practitioners managing M&As in emerging markets, emphasizing the critical importance of cultural due diligence and balanced integration approaches.

title: Energy Management Strategy Calibration Parameter Optimization for Planetary Hybrid Electric Vehicle

detail.title: Energy Management Strategy Calibration Parameter Optimization for Planetary Hybrid Electric Vehicle

keywords.keywords: Energy management strategy；Comprehensive fuel consumption；Calibration parameter optimization；Cooperative optimization

detail.abstract: Addressing the challenges of ambiguous optimization pathways and suboptimal energy conservation outcomes in hybrid commercial vehicle energy management, this study investigates collaborative calibration parameter optimization for energy management and control strategies. A longitudinal powertrain model was first established through integrated first-principles and data-driven modeling, with subsequent validation confirming its fidelity and a comprehensive fuel consumption estimation model was developed. Sobol global sensitivity analysis was then employed to quantify the influence of energy consumption parameters—and their interactions—on total vehicle fuel consumption. To overcome high-dimensional optimization barriers, we designed a Collaborative Coevolution Particle Swarm Optimization (CCPSO) algorithm, integrating uniform experimental design and parallel optimization within the Chaotic Particle Swarm Optimization (CPSO) foundation. The CCPSO-enabled strategy was benchmarked against conventional CPSO and Uniform Design CPSO (UD-CPSO) methods. Results demonstrate that CCPSO achieves a 20.90% reduction in fuel consumption—outperforming CPSO and UD-CPSO by over 3.44% across driving cycles.

title: Top-Down Growth Targets and Corporate Greening Practices
affiliations: Curtin University, Nanjing Audit University and International College of Management

detail.title: Top-Down Growth Targets and Corporate Greening Practices
detail.abstract: This study explores whether and how top-down amplification of economic growth targets influences corporate deceptive eco-behavior. We find that higher top-down amplification of economic growth targets significantly increases corporate greenwashing engagement through reduced financial input to environmental protection and lax government environmental regulation. This effect is more pronounced when firms are seeking green financing, are non-SOEs, face high target constraints, or operate during stable periods of government five-year plans. However, this weakens when firms face intensive environmental regulation or receive more government subsidies. Our research highlights a critical dilemma in emerging markets, characterized by substantial government intervention and intense economic growth demands, while simultaneously being required to meet net-zero targets. This paradox drives firms to engage in greenwashing as a survival strategy to comply with regulations, secure green financing, and meet growth goals.

detail.title: Field Testing and Simulation of Load Shifting for Grid-Interactive Heat Pump Systems Integrated with Thermal Energy Storage
detail.abstract: Integrating thermal energy storage (TES) into grid-interactive heat pump (HP) systems offers significant potential to enhance grid resilience and reduce building operating costs through effective load shifting. This study provides a detailed analysis of load shifting strategies and their impacts on cost savings and grid load. The TES unit is integrated with the HP system via a secondary loop, allowing cooling energy to be stored in phase change material (PCM) and heat transfer fluid (HTF) within the TES unit. The stored energy can later be discharged to provide cooling to the building, decoupling cooling generation from demand and enabling flexible operation. A field study is conducted to compare the TES-HP system with the nonTES-HP system, demonstrating the benefits of integrating TES. An evaluation matrix is proposed, including instantaneous performance, load-shifting performance, accumulated performance, unit-value indexes from both building and equipment perspectives, and peak-hour-only indexes, to comprehensively assess and compare the performance of the TES-HP and non-TES-HP systems. A rule-based control strategy, which considers variations in electricity prices and ambient temperature, is implemented to stabilize building thermal comfort, increase TES charging efficiency, and achieve load shifting. To further supplement the field study, simulation models are developed to analyze the impact of TES cooling storage capacity and heat transfer capability (UA, between the HTF and PCM in the TES unit) on load-shifting performance. Field test results indicate that, with the same thermostat setting, the TES-HP system can achieve hourly grid load reductions of 92%, 58%, and 36% during each peak hour, respectively, and a 39% reduction in 24-hour electricity costs compared to the non-TES-HP system. Isolating the effects of different cooling loads, TES-HP can increase cooling capacity per cost (QpC) by 6.6 times during the first peak hour and by 27% over the entire 24-hour field study period. Simulation results indicate that doubling the storage capacity of TES can reduce hourly cost and power consumption by up to 84.8% during peak hours and reduce 24-hour electricity costs by 38% compared with the original TES unit design. Increasing UA by 10 times can lead to a more than 25% reduction in 24-hour electricity costs, owing to improved system efficiency. In summary, field experiments and simulation studies demonstrate the strong potential of TES-HP systems to enhance energy flexibility and cost efficiency in grid-interactive buildings, making them a promising solution for energy management.

title: Lycaenid Brood Parasitism Optimization: A Novel Metaheuristic for Joint Dynamic Reconfiguration and Distributed Generation Allocation in Active Distribution Networks

detail.title: Lycaenid Brood Parasitism Optimization: A Novel Metaheuristic for Joint Dynamic Reconfiguration and Distributed Generation Allocation in Active Distribution Networks
detail.abstract: This paper introduces the Lycaenid Brood Parasitism Optimization Algorithm (LBPOA) for solving multi-objective optimization problems in Active Distribution Networks (ADNs). The method aims to optimize the simultaneous dynamic reconfiguration and allocation of Distributed Generation (DG) units and Battery Energy Storage Systems (BESS). A novel financial index is defined, incorporating operational costs, unreliability, energy purchase expenses, and switching event costs, with the additional consideration of minimizing CO₂, SO₂, and NOₓ emissions. The optimization problem is formulated dynamically, accounting for time-varying load demand and renewable energy generation, providing a more accurate representation of operational conditions compared to static methods. Simulation results for the typical 16-bus, IEEE 33-bus, and IEEE 69-bus test systems demonstrate the effectiveness of LBPOA in reducing operational costs, improving voltage quality, and reducing pollutant emissions. Specifically, LBPOA achieved a 39.06% reduction in power loss in the 16-bus system, a 36.63% reduction in the IEEE 33-bus system, and a 34.49% reduction in the IEEE 69-bus system. Furthermore, it improved the minimum voltage by 5.88%, 5.48%, and 4.21%, respectively. The method outperforms other state-of-the-art algorithms, including Multi-objective Particle Swarm Optimization (MOPSO), Non-dominated Sorting Genetic Algorithm II (NSGA-II), Multi-objective Harris Hawk Optimization (MOHHO), Multi-objective Cuckoo Search Algorithm (MOCSA), Multi-objective Ant Lion Optimizer (MOALO), Multi-objective Flower Pollination Algorithm (MOFPA), Multi-objective Grey Wolf Optimizer (MOGWO), and Multi-objective Bat Algorithm (MOBAT), in terms of solution quality and convergence speed. These results confirm LBPOA's robustness, efficiency, and potential for large-scale deployment in real-world ADN applications.

detail.title: The Relationship between the Internationalization of Family Firms and the Dimensions of Their Socioemotional Weatlh According to the Fiber Scale
detail.abstract: AbsractThis study examines the relationship between the degree of internationalization and the five dimensions of socioemotional wealth (SEW), operationalized through the FIBER scale, in family firms. Using survey data from 117 Hungarian family businesses, firms were classified into three levels of internationalization—non-international, exporters, and firms operating through own foreign subsidiaries. Results reveal a statistically significant inverse relationship between internationalization depth and the “Family Influence and Control” dimension, indicating that strong control preferences may constrain deeper international market engagement. A marginally significant difference emerges in “Emotional Attachment,” while “Family Business Identity,” “Binding Social Ties,” and “Transgenerational Succession Intent” remain stable regardless of internationalization level. Cluster analysis identifies four distinct SEW profiles—Family-Dominated, Strong Control, Weak Control, and Market-Oriented—each showing unique patterns of international involvement.Theoretically, the study advances family business research by (1) refining the understanding of how individual SEW dimensions differentially relate to the depth of internationalization, challenging the prevailing assumption that SEW uniformly constrains cross-border expansion; (2) extending the application of the FIBER framework to capture nuanced patterns across varying internationalization pathways; and (3) highlighting the persistent resilience of certain non-economic goals, such as identity and succession intent, even under higher degrees of international exposure.For practicing leaders, a key takeaway is the importance of consciously managing control. Delegating the leadership of international expansion—particularly to a well-trained family member—can preserve socioemotional value while, if successful, positioning that family member as a strong successor candidate in the succession process. Future research could integrate geographic, industry-specific, and longitudinal perspectives, and extend the analysis to other Central and Eastern European countries.

detail.title: Progressive Anti-Deference

publicationDetails.journalName: Texas A&M University School of Law Legal Studies Research Paper Series

detail.abstract: On the surface, the overturning of Chevron deference seems like yet another win for the conservative, antiregulatory movement that has risen to power in American politics. On this account, and if all goes according to plan, courts will now be freed to limit agencies' statutory powers and thereby tame or deconstruct the administrative state. Yet developments in the law often have unintended consequences, and it may be that Loper Bright's rejection of deference will not inexorably move administrative law and regulatory policy in a less protective direction. This article shows that, taken to its logical implications, the formalistic theory of interpretation that the Loper Bright majority espoused compels greater scrutiny of all forms of agency error, including errors that involve the agency failing to regulate as much or as stringently as the best reading of statutes requires. More systematically, this would entail revisiting several areas of administrative law doctrine that put a thumb on the scale in favor of deferential review of agency inaction. As they currently stand, these standards of review are incompatible with Loper Bright's theory of interpretation. This article identifies these implications, argues that an asymmetrical approach to different types of errors that agencies might commit is undesirable for administrative law, and urges litigants and judges to begin the hard work of unpacking and faithfully pursuing Loper Bright's full implications, which may often involve a boon to those who government fails by doing less than Congress required.

title: The Cost of Transparency: Mutual Funds’ Higher Reporting Frequency and Corporate Environmental Liabilities
affiliations: University of Essex, EBS, University of Nottingham, affiliation not provided to SSRN and University of Science and Technology Beijing

detail.title: The Cost of Transparency: Mutual Funds’ Higher Reporting Frequency and Corporate Environmental Liabilities
detail.abstract: This paper examines the effect of the 2004 SEC regulation change, which increased the frequency of mutual funds’ portfolio disclosures, on corporate environmental liabilities. Employing a difference-in-differences approach, we find that firms with greater mutual fund ownership affected by the regulatory change significantly increased their environmental liabilities. Further analyses suggest that this increase in corporate environmental liabilities stems from firms’ responses to heightened performance pressures, as fund managers became more focused on short-term outcomes following the regulatory change. Overall, our findings highlight the potential socials costs associated with increased mutual funds transparency.

title: The Impact of Indirect Cost Factors on Infrastructure Projects
affiliations: Arizona State University

detail.title: The Impact of Indirect Cost Factors on Infrastructure Projects
detail.abstract: Whether it’s administrative overhead, project management fees, economic changes, or other factors, in this case, we strived to understand why some of the hidden costs are significant to the budgets and outcomes of large-scale infrastructure projects. Unlike the ‘clean’ approach, we collected and analyzed quantitative data from multiple industries, including healthcare, and conducted a systematic analysis. Our analysis showed the hidden costs that many people pass over are, in fact, critical for the outcome of the project. It was found that due to poor economic management, a fraction of an expense would reduce economic stability. Moreover, in addition to this economic resiliency, the problem of poorly managed project management arises, where under-managed projects will constantly add to delays and thus cause an upsurge in expenses. The unexpected results came from trying to improve the handling of administrative tasks within the project; these tiny tweaks led to a 15% enhancement in project performance, which was surprising. Our research is especially important in healthcare, where new patient-centered infrastructure is not an optional add-on, but a vital component that bolsters patient care services. Moreover, the findings of the study serve as a strong guide for both policymakers and investors when assessing the financial sustainability of these proposed initiatives becomes simpler. This need for responsiveness to planning can be aligned with our findings,  where transparent approaches towards indirect costs result in direct savings when such planned spending encourages better budget control.

title: A Cyber-Physical Cooperative Restoration Strategy for Distribution Systems Based on Uav Relay Communications

detail.title: A Cyber-Physical Cooperative Restoration Strategy for Distribution Systems Based on Uav Relay Communications
detail.abstract: After the occurrence of natural disasters, the restoration of the distribution system (DS) often faces the challenge of failed distribution automation (DA) functions due to damaged communication infrastructure, which significantly prolongs the load restoration process. Unmanned aerial vehicles (UAVs), being less affected by terrain and environmental conditions, can provide various emergency communication services in disaster-affected areas. This paper proposes a cyber-physical cooperative restoration strategy for DS based on UAV relay communications. To ensure the accessibility of communication links, a multi-UAV relay system channel transmission rate model is constructed. Aiming to maximize load restoration while minimizing UAV flight distances, the model comprehensively considers UAV operation and communication recovery constraints, load restoration constraints, and cyber-physical coupling constraints, and incorporates time sequence considerations to establish an integrated cooperative restoration model. This problem is formulated as a mixed-integer nonlinear programming (MINLP) problem. An embedded constraint method based on deep neural networks (DNNs) is adopted to transform it into a mixed-integer second-order cone programming (MISOCP) problem. Furthermore, to accelerate the solution process, an L1-norm-based unstructured network pruning technique is designed to further improve the computational efficiency of the optimization problem embedded within DNNs. The results demonstrate that the proposed cooperative restoration strategy can fully exploit the restoration potential of the UAV relay system and enhance DS resilience.

title: Intelligent Decision-Making for Energy Dispatch in Lng Receiving Stations: High-Precision Prediction Models and Adaptive Energy Efficiency Optimization

detail.title: Intelligent Decision-Making for Energy Dispatch in Lng Receiving Stations: High-Precision Prediction Models and Adaptive Energy Efficiency Optimization
detail.abstract: Enhancing the energy efficiency of liquefied natural gas (LNG) receiving stations is pivotal for advancing the low-carbon transition of energy systems while simultaneously improving operational cost-effectiveness. However, existing energy consumption forecasting approaches, which typically rely on single algorithms, often fall short in predictive accuracy and adaptability. To address these limitations, we propose a high-precision forecasting and operational optimization framework that integrates multi-model ensemble learning with intelligent dispatch optimization. By leveraging HYSYS process simulations and distributed control system (DCS) operational data, we systematically analyze the key drivers of energy consumption across critical equipment, including low-temperature submersible pumps, high-pressure pumps, seawater pumps, and boil-off gas (BOG) compressors. We construct a stacked ensemble prediction model, optimized using Optuna, by incorporating multiple machine learning algorithms as base learners. Building upon this, we design a hybrid simulated annealing-particle swarm optimization (SA-PSO) algorithm enhanced with adaptive parameter tuning strategies, which enables global optimization of equipment start-stop combinations and operational parameters. Our results demonstrate that the proposed model significantly improves prediction accuracy, achieving an overall R² exceeding 0.95. Under three representative gas delivery scenarios (800, 1230, and 1450 m³/h), the optimization strategy reduces total system energy consumption by 3.7%, 4.8%, and 6.2%, respectively. Furthermore, across the full operational flow range, the method consistently reduces energy use by 2.76% to 6.20%, underscoring its strong engineering applicability and potential for broader deployment.

title: How Firms Spread Good Management
affiliations: Stanford University - Department of Economics, Stanford University, Harvard University - Strategy Unit, Federal Reserve Banks - Federal Reserve Bank of New York and Massachusetts Institute of Technology (MIT)

detail.title: How Firms Spread Good Management

publicationDetails.journalName: Federal Reserve Bank of New York Research Paper Series

detail.abstract:
What is good management, and how is it transmitted across firms and plants? In a recent paper, we use survey and administrative data, coupled with a structural model of management, to explore these questions. We show that well-managed manufacturing firms—that is, firms that adopt more structured management practices described below—not only open and acquire more plants, but also close and sell more plants. Through this process, the firms transmit their management practices to new plants. These facts, taken together, imply that acquisitions can increase aggregate productivity by allowing well-managed firms to take over poorly managed plants and improve their management practices.

title: Enhancing Safety Signaling: Integrating Clinical Trials and Post-Marketing Adverse Event Reports
affiliations: University of California, Los Angeles (UCLA) - Anderson School of Management, University of California, Berkeley and University of Maryland - Robert H. Smith School of Business

detail.title: Enhancing Safety Signaling: Integrating Clinical Trials and Post-Marketing Adverse Event Reports

declarations.declarationOfInterest: No conflict of interest to declare.

detail.abstract:
Problem definition: Adverse drug reactions (ADRs) cause numerous emergency room visits and thousands of deaths annually in the U.S. Although regulators like the Food and Drug Administration (FDA) aim to detect safety issues during clinical trials, these trials are often too small, short, or restrictive to capture rare or delayed ADRs. Consequently, regulators rely on spontaneous adverse event reporting systems (e.g., FAERS) to identify potential safety issues-termed safety signals-by detecting side effects that occur disproportionately among patients taking a particular drug. However, these observational data are subject to selection and reporting biases, which can lead to false signals or missed risks. 

Methodology/results: We propose a Bayesian framework to enhance the hypothesis generation step in safety signaling, offering two methodological advances over standard approaches that rely solely on observational data. First, it integrates pre-approval clinical trial and post-approval observational data. Second, it uses information from common ADRs to estimate and correct bias in rare ADRs. We assess the approach using an analytical model and a large-scale numerical study with real clinical trial and FAERS data. Incorporating clinical trial data substantially reduces signaling costs, and using a common ADR for debiasing yields further gains. This refinement improves decisions for about 1% of ADRs, translating to expected cost savings of 1.5-2.3% (approx. $32-159 million), with performance robust to moderate parameter misspecification. 

Managerial implications: By using existing regulatory data, our approach supports a more efficient and timely hypothesis generation process in post-approval surveillance.

title: Integrating Industry 4.0 into Hospital Waste Management (Hwm4.0): A Framework and Application of the Novel Interval Cocoso Method

detail.title: Integrating Industry 4.0 into Hospital Waste Management (Hwm4.0): A Framework and Application of the Novel Interval Cocoso Method

keywords: the interval Combined Compromise Solution (CoCoSo) method

detail.abstract: Hospital Waste Management (HWM) plays a critical role in enhancing the quality of healthcare services, particularly when supported by emerging technologies. The present study aims to develop a comprehensive framework for integrating HWM with Industry 4.0 technologies—herein referred to as HWM 4.0. The originality of this research lies in two main contributions: first, the conceptualization and introduction of the HWM 4.0 framework; and second, the application of the Combinatorial-Interval Compromise Solution (CoCoSo) method, which is employed for the first time in this context. To achieve the research objectives, the study initially identifies and categorizes HWM-related activities, subsequently mapping the role of Industry 4.0 technologies in each category. The control activities within hospitals are classified into seven key domains: human resources, infrastructure and equipment, financial management, operations and processes, energy efficiency and waste reduction, information systems and technology, and biological risk control and safety. The study then introduces the Combinatorial-Interval CoCoSo method and demonstrates its practical applicability through two case studies involving eight hospitals, where hospitals are prioritized based on the identified control activities. Ultimately, the study proposes a structured framework for the implementation and evaluation of HWM 4.0, providing valuable insights for both researchers and practitioners in the healthcare and waste management sectors.

title: Forecasting Realized Volatility Using Har Models and Wavelet Decomposition: A Volatility-Timing Perspective
affiliations: Queensland University of Technology - School of Economics and Finance and University of the Sunshine Coast

detail.title: Forecasting Realized Volatility Using Har Models and Wavelet Decomposition: A Volatility-Timing Perspective
detail.abstract: This study proposes a wavelet-based approach to forecasting Realized Volatility (RV) and evaluates its economic value within a volatility-timing framework. We apply wavelet decomposition to separate short-, medium-, and long-term components and generate forecasts using Heterogeneous Autoregressive (HAR) models. Forecasts based on the low-frequency component consistently lead to better portfolio outcomes, reducing turnover and enhancing investor utility without increasing risk. These results hold even when portfolio weights are forecast directly after being constructed from RV, or when jump-robust volatility estimates are used. The results highlight the importance of aligning forecast evaluation with practical investment objectives. Forecasts delivering the greatest welfare gains may not minimize conventional statistical loss functions.

title: Laughter as a Resource for Mitigating Conflict and Reframing Norms During Joint Interaction
affiliations: Pontificia Universidad Católica de Chile, Pontificia Universidad Católica de Chile and Pontificia Universidad Católica de Chile

detail.title: Laughter as a Resource for Mitigating Conflict and Reframing Norms During Joint Interaction
detail.abstract: This article explores the role of laughter in managing normative ambiguity and interpersonal tension during joint activity. Through close analysis of a situated cooking task involving four international students, we examine how participants use laughter to negotiate the interpretation of an underspecified instruction and their roles during the task. Two excerpts from the early stages of the interaction are analyzed using Jeffersonian transcription and a sequential approach to laughter. The analysis reveals that laughter supports both the mitigation of face-threatening acts and the tacit redefinition of shared goals, without resorting to explicit deliberation. It mediates tensions between diverging intentions and helps participants realign around a common objective—namely, collective enjoyment. Rather than functioning solely as a face-saving mechanism, laughter operates as a multi-level pragmatic resource: it enables conflict resolution, relational alignment, and the reframing of the normative structure of the activity. These findings expand current models of mitigation by showing how laughter contributes not only to local facework but also to broader discursive shifts in joint action. The study contributes to pragmatics by highlighting the role of laughter in reorganizing interactional norms in real time.

title: Dispatch Optimization for Ambulance and Emergency Service Systems
affiliations: University of Michigan at Ann Arbor - Department of Industrial and Operations Engineering, Hong Kong University of Science & Technology (HKUST) and Hong Kong University of Science & Technology (HKUST) - Department of Information Systems, Business Statistics and Operations Management

detail.title: Dispatch Optimization for Ambulance and Emergency Service Systems

declarations.declarationOfInterest: There are no personal or financial conflicts of interest related to this work.

detail.abstract: Emergency Medical Services (EMS) face critical challenges in optimizing ambulance dispatch policies to minimize response times and operational costs, particularly under nonstationary demand processes across multiple service classes. Traditional static dispatch strategies, such as deploying the nearest available unit, often lead to suboptimal resource allocation and coverage gaps during high-demand periods, especially when dealing with varying emergency call priorities and service requirements. Existing approaches largely focus on stationary demand models or rely on computationally intensive methods such as Markov decision processes that are impractical for large-scale systems. This paper addresses these limitations by proposing a dynamic dispatch framework that adapts to real-time demand fluctuations and system states, offering a scalable solution to enhance EMS efficiency in time-varying environments with heterogeneous service types. We introduce two simple heuristic policies: a static policy derived from a deterministic linear program with buffer capacity and a dynamic policy that adjusts dispatch probabilities using real-time information. Both approaches explicitly account for multiple service classes with distinct response time requirements and resource consumption patterns. Theoretical analysis shows that these policies achieve asymptotic optimality gaps of O(θ-1/2 log 1/2 θ) and O(θ-2/3 log θ), respectively, where θ is a system size-scaling parameter. We further extend our framework to accommodate i) high-variance demand patterns that cannot be adequately represented by traditional Bernoulli processes, and ii) light traffic regime, and we show that all the results extend to these settings as well. Numerical experiments demonstrate that our proposed solutions perform very well compared to existing methods, particularly under nonstationary demand patterns and complicated systems. These results highlight the practical viability of adaptive dispatch controls in improving EMS performance while balancing computational efficiency and theoretical rigor.

title: Sustainable Management Strategies for Ecosystem Services in Coastal Cities: Driving Mechanisms of Ecosystem Services Supply and Demand Relationships Based on G-Xgboost Model
affiliations: affiliation not provided to SSRN, affiliation not provided to SSRN, Shandong University of Science and Technology, affiliation not provided to SSRN, affiliation not provided to SSRN and affiliation not provided to SSRN

detail.title: Sustainable Management Strategies for Ecosystem Services in Coastal Cities: Driving Mechanisms of Ecosystem Services Supply and Demand Relationships Based on G-Xgboost Model
detail.abstract: Under the dual pressures of urbanization and climate change, the supply-demand imbalance of ecosystem services (ESs) in coastal cities has become increasingly pronounced, posing a critical challenge to regional sustainable development. Clarifying the driving mechanisms behind ESs supply-demand relationships (ESSDR) and formulating sustainable management strategies accordingly are essential for achieving the supply-demand balance of ESs. Taking Qingdao as a case study, this research quantified six types of ESs—food production, water yield, marine aquaculture, carbon sequestration, soil retention, and recreational capacity—over the period from 2002 to 2022. On this basis, an innovative Geographical-XGBoost (G-XGBoost) model was employed to investigate the spatial heterogeneity of influencing factors across different geographical units. This approach revealed the underlying driving mechanisms of ESSDR in coastal cities and informed the development of spatially targeted strategies for sustainable ESs management. The results indicate that: (1) The urban core and southern coastal areas are major deficit zones in Qingdao, while the northern agricultural areas and mountainous regions are surplus zones. (2) From 2002 to 2022, urban expansion emerged as the primary driving force of ESSDR in coastal cities. Significant spatial interactions exist between the built-up land proportion (BLP) and factors such as cultivated land proportion (CLP), potential evapotranspiration (PET), and distance to ports (DTP). When BLP exceeds 30%, the negative impacts of urban expansion are significantly intensified under conditions where CLP is below 40%, or PET exceeds 1000 mm, or DTP is less than 20 km. (3) The impact of these influencing factors on ESSDR differs across different geographical units. Accordingly, region-specific management strategies were proposed based on the dominant factors in each area. These findings provide both a technical framework and theoretical foundation for the precise formulation of ESs sustainable management strategies in coastal cities globally.

title: Route Icing Risk Modelling for Arctic Marine Operations: A Predictive Framework for Enhanced Operational Planning
affiliations: UiT The Arctic University of Norway, affiliation not provided to SSRN and affiliation not provided to SSRN

detail.title: Route Icing Risk Modelling for Arctic Marine Operations: A Predictive Framework for Enhanced Operational Planning
detail.abstract: Ship operations in the Arctic face significant challenges from icing, particularly during winter seasons. Icing on vessel surfaces poses serious risks, including reduced stability that can lead to capsizing in the worst case. The International Maritime Organization (IMO)’s Polar Code mandates that ship operators assess and mitigate icing risks during operational planning. However, the absence of specific route risk models or metrics hinders effective implementation of these regulations. This study introduces a route icing risk model to estimate the spatial-temporal icing risk of Arctic voyages, leveraging existing icing rate prediction models and weather forecasts. Using actual ship trip data and reanalysis weather data from 2021 to 2023, the study identifies severe icing thresholds for the estimation of severe icing events. Ten ship trips were analysed to compare route icing risk predictions based on forecast data versus reanalysis data, revealing significant discrepancies. The study also examines the effects of route discretization intervals, speed changes, and waypoint adjustments on route icing risk estimation. Results indicate that larger discretization intervals may underestimate risk, while waypoint deviations have a greater impact on icing risk than speed adjustments. Both factors have limited influence when arrival times are fixed comparing with arrival time not fixed. A case study demonstrates the model’s application for multi-objective fishing route optimization, balancing icing risk, trip duration, and catch maximization. This model provides a valuable tool for risk-informed decision-making, accident prevention, and regulatory compliance in Arctic marine operations.

title: From Micro to Macro: Can Machines Unlock New Real-Time Economic Signals from Firm-Level Accounting Data?
affiliations: Central University of Finance and Economics (CUFE) - School of Economics and Central University of Finance and Economics (CUFE) - School of Economics

detail.title: From Micro to Macro: Can Machines Unlock New Real-Time Economic Signals from Firm-Level Accounting Data?
detail.abstract: This paper investigates whether machines can unlock new real-time economic signals from firm-level accounting data. We develop the Firm-level Accounting data-based Machine Learning (FAML) framework, which applies machine learning algorithms directly to firm-level corporate financial reports to nowcast aggregate economic output. Unlike "aggregate-then-nowcast" approaches, which average firm-level variables into market or sector aggregates, or "factor-then-nowcast" methods, which extract common factors via dynamic factor models, our FAML method operates on the full set of firm-level accounting variables, retaining the informational detail embedded in firm-level heterogeneity and cross-firm interactions while minimizing information loss. Empirically, the FAML framework reduces root mean squared error by over 70% relative to a random walk benchmark and consistently outperforms both aggregation- and factor-based methods. Variable importance analysis further shows that accounting data from the industrials, utilities, and consumer discretionary sectors are particularly informative for economic output nowcasting. These findings underscore the value of leveraging machine learning to transform micro-level accounting data into timely macroeconomic insights.
