detail.abstract: Passive liquidity providers (LPs) in automated market makers (AMMs) face losses due to adverse selection (LVR), which static trading fees often fail to offset in practice. We study the key determinants of LP profitability in a dynamic reduced-form model where an AMM operates in parallel with a centralized exchange (CEX), traders route their orders optimally to the venue offering the better price, and arbitrageurs exploit price discrepancies. Using large-scale simulations and real market data, we analyze how LP profits vary with market conditions such as volatility and trading volume, and characterize the optimal AMM fee as a function of these conditions. We highlight the mechanisms driving these relationships through extensive comparative statics, and confirm the model's relevance through market data calibration. A key trade-off emerges: fees must be low enough to attract volume, yet high enough to earn sufficient revenues and mitigate arbitrage losses. We find that under normal market conditions, the optimal AMM fee is competitive with the trading cost on the CEX and remarkably stable, whereas in periods of very high volatility, a high fee protects passive LPs from severe losses. These findings suggest that a threshold-type dynamic fee schedule is both robust enough to market conditions and improves LP outcomes.

title: Which Factors Influence Physicians’ Decision-Making Towards Resuscitation Attitudes? A Vignette-Based Study
affiliations: affiliation not provided to SSRN, Institute of Social and Preventive Medicine (IUMSP), Lausanne University Hospital , affiliation not provided to SSRN, University of Lausanne - Lausanne University Hospital and affiliation not provided to SSRN

detail.title: Which Factors Influence Physicians’ Decision-Making Towards Resuscitation Attitudes? A Vignette-Based Study
detail.abstract: Aim: To identify physician and patient characteristics influencing physicians’ resuscitation decision-making.Methods: Monocentric, experimental vignette study in a tertiary university hospital, using a self-report online vignette questionnaire. Each questionnaire contained eleven demographic questions and five clinical vignettes. Three vignettes had one variable altered between two groups and two vignettes were identical in the two groups. Participants were physicians working in hospital wards admitting adult, somatic patients. Physicians were randomly assigned to one of the two groups and had to decide for a resuscitation in case of a cardiac arrest.Results: 303 out of 724 physicians (41.8%) from 18 wards responded. Physicians from surgery departments were significantly (p<0.001) more likely to resuscitate than those from the medicine department in four vignettes (multimorbidity, oncology, dementia and neurology vignettes). Physicians with an experience in ICU were significantly (p<0.05) less likely to recommend resuscitation in three vignettes (multimorbidity, oncology and dementia vignettes). Two patient variables were significantly (p<0.001) associated with a decision to resuscitate: patient being a physician themself vs. not (33.1% vs. 15.8%); patient of younger age vs. older (61.5% vs. 25.5%) despite a terminally ill condition. Participants overall were more likely to resuscitate in comparison with expert advice in four vignettes (multimorbidity, oncology, dementia and neurology vignettes).Conclusions: Physicians’ own characteristics contribute to heterogeneity in decision-making. Physicians’ resuscitation attitudes are influenced by patient factors that may not be related to resuscitation outcomes. These results raise important ethical considerations and highlight the need for specific training about resuscitation outcomes and reflexiveness in decision-making.

title: Polarization Image Enhancement Method Based on Federated Learning
affiliations: Capital Normal University and Capital Normal University

detail.title: Polarization Image Enhancement Method Based on Federated Learning
detail.abstract: Polarized images have significant application value in optical research and computer vision. Collaborative training of polarized images can effectively integrate multi-source data and enhance the generalization ability and performance of models. However, due to the fact that these data are usually distributed across multiple devices and have high privacy sensitivity, such as distributed devices or terminals equipped with polarized cameras, direct central training may face the risk of data leakage and insufficient privacy protection. To address this issue, this paper proposes a polarization image enhancement method based on federated learning to effectively safeguard data privacy. To optimize the model aggregation in the federated learning framework, a loss-weighted aggregation strategy is designed, combining multi-source information from each client to construct a global model for distributed low-light image enhancement. Experiments conducted on two real-world datasets demonstrate that the proposed method not only significantly reduces training time but also outperforms traditional centralized methods in terms of privacy protection.To ensure reproducibility, the source code and demonstration videos can be found at https://pan.baidu.com/s/1dzWMZgnGYl92uyabAkfhXQ (Extraction code: zs6h).

title: How and Why Students Use Ai Chatbots in Economics Classes: Evidence from Student Surveys
affiliations: affiliation not provided to SSRN and Whitman College

detail.title: How and Why Students Use Ai Chatbots in Economics Classes: Evidence from Student Surveys
detail.abstract: While much has been written about what AI chatbots can do, very little has been written about how students actually use them in economics classes. The purpose of this paper is to investigate how and why economics students use AI chatbots, and to better understand if AI chatbot usage prevents students from learning. To do this we draw on a structured questionnaire as well as class discussions with students. We find that 1) the majority of students use AI chatbots to help them learn, 2) the majority of students know how to use AI appropriately, and, 3) students’ fear that AI will produce inaccurate information and their desire to learn are the primary deterrents to using AI chatbots inappropriately. Based on these results, we discuss some implications for instructors to consider when developing their AI chatbot policies.

title: Accountability Among Child Protection Workers: Definitions, Perceived Impacts, and Coping Strategies
affiliations: University of Montreal, University of Montreal and University of Montreal

detail.title: Accountability Among Child Protection Workers: Definitions, Perceived Impacts, and Coping Strategies
detail.abstract: BackgroundIn Quebec, Canada, child protection (CP) services operate within a complex system that places significant responsibility on child protection workers (CPWs). Tasked with decisions that profoundly affect children and families, CPWs must remain accountable for their actions. This accountability requirement can heighten vulnerability, contributing to stress and compassion fatigue. Despite its central role in CP practice, accountability remains poorly defined in the scientific literature, with limited insight into its impact on CPWs' daily work.ObjectiveThis study examines Quebec CPWs’ experience of accountability by exploring (1) how they define it, (2) its impact on their personal and professional lives, and (3) the strategies they use to cope with it.Participants and SettingData for this study were drawn from a larger investigation on workplace psychological health involving 310 CPWs in the Greater Montreal area. This analysis focuses on a subsample of 30 CPWs.MethodsThis exploratory qualitative study relies on a thematic analysis of anonymized transcripts of telephone interviews.ResultsParticipants defined accountability as a combination of professional, organizational, legal, and medical responsibilities inherent to CP work. Most reported negative effects, including stress, anxiety, reduced sense of competence, and work overload. Clinical support from colleagues and supervisors emerged as the most effective coping strategy.ConclusionsThis study reveals accountability as a complex, dynamic, and systemic experience for Quebec CPWs, significantly shaping their practice and well-being. Enhancing supervisory support and fostering peer collaboration could reduce stress and strengthen resilience, ultimately supporting better service outcomes and worker retention.

title: Can Promoting E-Commerce Development Boost Consumption?
affiliations: Southwest Minzu University and China West Normal University

detail.title: Can Promoting E-Commerce Development Boost Consumption?
detail.abstract: Amid the rapid and sustained growth of the e-commerce economy and the active implementation of China's strategies to expand domestic demand, the influence of promoting e-commerce development on consumption has garnered widespread attention from various sectors. This study utilizes panel data from Chinese cities at the prefecture level and above from 2001 to 2019, treating the construction of national e-commerce demonstration cities as a quasi-natural experiment of China's local government efforts to promote e-commerce development. Using The propensity score matching difference-in-differences (PSM-DID) model, this research empirically examines the overall and dynamic effects of promoting e-commerce development on consumption, analyzes the heterogeneity and progressivity of these effects, and verifies the underlying mechanisms. The findings show that: Overall, promoting e-commerce development has a positive impact on consumption, and this positive impact continues to strengthen over time; the influence of promoting e-commerce development on consumption varies according to the foundational conditions of urban development and the consumption levels of individual cities; promoting e-commerce development can positively influence consumption through mechanisms such as enhancing technological innovation levels, increasing fixed asset investment, and raising urban residents' income, with greater impact on enterprise consumption expansion than on household consumption growth.

title: Impetus of E-Customer Satisfaction and its Effects on E-Customer Loyalty- an Sem Approach on App-Based Instant Home Delivery Services
affiliations: Jashore University of Science and Technology, HSTU and BGMEA University of Fashion & Technology (BUFT)

detail.title: Impetus of E-Customer Satisfaction and its Effects on E-Customer Loyalty- an Sem Approach on App-Based Instant Home Delivery Services
detail.abstract: Despite extensive research on the application of the SERVQUAL model for measuring service quality, limited attention has been given to extending this model to the context of mobile app-based instant home delivery services. To address this issue, we intend to examine the effects of mobile app’s service quality dimension on e-customer satisfaction, subsequently on e-customer loyalty drawing upon both the SERVQUAL and Technology Acceptance Model (TAM) frameworks. To evaluate their effects, the responses (n=605) were collected from the mobile apps’ users for instant home delivery services using a questionnaire survey. The data were analyzed by the AMOS v-24 and PROCESS Macro v-4.20 software through the lens of Structural Equation Modeling (SEM). The results reveal that visual organization of the mobile apps, reliability, responsiveness, user-friendliness, and personal need fulfilment are the crucial predictors of e-customer satisfaction, which also can be turned into the e-customer loyalty. Furthermore, the study examines the mediating role of e-customer satisfaction in the proposed relationships. Our research contributes to the validation and extension of the SERVQUAL and TAM frameworks, offering practical implications for scholars and policymakers involved in managing mobile app-based instant home delivery services. The findings of this study have a significant impact on app developers and marketers in the instant home delivery sector. Identifying the primary quality aspects that influence customer satisfaction and loyalty in e-services provide valuable guidelines for enhancing app development. It is also significant for its focus on emerging markets, as it sheds light on how consumers behave in rapidly changing digital environments.

title: Community-Led Disaster Resilience: Strengthening Preparedness and Recovery in Regional Australia
affiliations: Coimbra University, Australian Red Cross and Independent Consultant

detail.title: Community-Led Disaster Resilience: Strengthening Preparedness and Recovery in Regional Australia
detail.abstract: Community-led disaster resilience is an emerging framework in disaster risk reduction that emphasises local leadership, grassroots coordination and adaptive strategies to enhance preparedness and recovery. It is based on community knowledge, lived experience of emergency events and readiness to contribute towards their own resilience with the help of external organisations. This paper explores community-led resilience models through the case study of the Australian Red Cross Community-Led Resilience Teams (CRT) program in regional New South Wales in Australia. Drawing on qualitative empirical data from the evaluation of the program in 2024, we analyse the strengths of community-led resilience efforts including their ability to enhance trust, social cohesion, and responsiveness to local needs. We also critically examine key challenges, such as sustaining long-term engagement, navigating resource limitations, and ensuring inclusivity, particularly in reaching marginalised groups. Our research shows that the success of community-led resilience is predicated on four essential factors: It requires for the community to be motivated to get involved; it is based on capacity and leadership within the community to manage emerging structures for resilience building; the timing for resilience-building needs to be right; and external services must be available to support the community in their efforts. This paper contributes to the broader conceptual understanding of how communities can be supported and empowered to drive their own resilience-building strategies. We offer insights for policymakers and practitioners on fostering sustainable, scalable, and inclusive community resilience, emphasising the role of community leadership in shaping disaster preparedness and response.

title: Vibe Coding as a Reconfiguration of Intent Mediation in Software Development: Definition, Implications, and Research Agenda
affiliations: Ruhr University of Bochum, Ruhr University Bochum, Ruhr University Bochum, Ruhr University Bochum and Ruhr University Bochum

detail.title: Vibe Coding as a Reconfiguration of Intent Mediation in Software Development: Definition, Implications, and Research Agenda
detail.abstract: Software development is undergoing a fundamental transformation as vibe coding becomes widespread, with large portions of contemporary codebases now being AI-generated. The disconnect between rapid adoption and limited conceptual understanding highlights the need for an inquiry into this emerging paradigm. Drawing on an intent perspective and historical analysis, we define vibe coding as a software development paradigm where humans and generative AI engage in collaborative flow to co-create software artifacts through natural language dialogue, shifting the mediation of developer intent from deterministic instruction to probabilistic inference. By intent mediation, we refer to the fundamental process through which developers translate their conceptual goals into representations that computational systems can execute. Our results show that vibe coding reconfigures cognitive work by redistributing epistemic labor between humans and machines, shifting the expertise in the software development process away from traditional areas such as design or technical implementation toward collaborative orchestration. We identify key opportunities, including democratization, acceleration, and systemic leverage, alongside risks, such as black box codebases, responsibility gaps, and ecosystem bias. We conclude with a research agenda spanning human-, technology-, and organization-centered directions to guide future investigations of this paradigm.

title: OntoMotoOS Collective Intelligence Protocol for Multi-AI Cooperative Governance (Part 3 of the OntoMotoOS Conceptual Framework Series)
affiliations: Independent Researcher, South Korea

detail.title: OntoMotoOS Collective Intelligence Protocol for Multi-AI Cooperative Governance (Part 3 of the OntoMotoOS Conceptual Framework Series)
detail.abstract:
This paper presents the Collective Intelligence Protocol (CIP), the third component of the OntoMotoOS conceptual framework, designed to enable cooperative governance among heterogeneous Artificial Intelligence (AI) systems.

While Part 1 outlined a holistic governance roadmap and Part 2 developed the Value-Based Logical Safety Filter for risk detection and mitigation, this work focuses on collaborative decision-making, distributed risk assessment, and consensus formation in multi-AI environments.

The CIP is conceptually designed to:

  • Facilitate decentralized yet ethically aligned governance processes.

  • Integrate dynamic trust scoring and reputation mechanisms across AI nodes.

  • Apply the Annex, Gate, and Phoenix meta-protocols for conflict resolution, emergency intervention, and system recovery.

  • Harmonize domain-specific vocabularies and ethical imperatives through ontological mapping to ensure interpretability and fairness.

The framework supports theoretical compatibility with blockchain-based governance logs, post-quantum encryption, and sector-specific coordination in domains such as autonomous medicine, finance, and critical infrastructure.

No physical or operational implementation has been performed at this stage; the design remains conceptual, supported by simulation-ready specifications, governance flow diagrams, and proposed pilot testing pathways.

title: Digital Leadership Edge: Chairman Traits and Digital Transformation
affiliations: Cheung Kong Graduate School of Business, Stanford Digital Economy Lab and Cheung Kong Graduate School of Business

detail.title: Digital Leadership Edge: Chairman Traits and Digital Transformation
detail.abstract: Digital leadership, the ability to envision, strategize, and execute technology-driven organizational transformation, is increasingly vital for firm adaptation in the digital economy. This study explores the pivotal role of top leadership in driving digital transformation in emerging markets, a strategic frontier for digital and AI growth where top-down strategy prevails. Focusing on China, a key arena for digital advancement, we conceptualize digital leadership as a multi-dimensional, trait-based capability shaped by personal and professional attributes. Analyzing over 4,000 Chinese A-share listed firms (2016-2021), our mixed-method approach investigates not only whether chairmen lead digital transformation, but also what determines their capacity to do so. We identify key chairperson traits-technical background, R&D experience, and long-term orientation-as predictors of digital strategy emphasis and talent acquisition. Clustering reveals four leadership archetypes: technocrats, practitioners, agents, and grassroots leaders, with varying impacts on transformation outcomes. Technocrats and practitioners show better digital leadership, with technocrats excelling in private firms and mature governance systems, while agents play a larger role in SOEs under institutional constraints. To reinforce the link between chairman characteristics and digital transformation, we exploit staggered digital government reforms as a quasi-exogenous shock and identify a causal effect between the political embeddedness of chairmen and enhanced digital transformation. The study is among the first to study how digital leadership-shaped by individual traits and institutional alignment-addresses transformation challenges in emerging markets. Our findings highlight how leadership shapes organizational digital growth.

title: Security and Privacy Challenges in Cloud-Based Database Management: Strategies and Solutions
affiliations: affiliation not provided to SSRN, affiliation not provided to SSRN and affiliation not provided to SSRN

detail.title: Security and Privacy Challenges in Cloud-Based Database Management: Strategies and Solutions
detail.abstract: The many benefits of scalability, affordability, and accessibility are driving the growing popularity of database management systems hosted in the cloud. But new security and privacy concerns arise as a result of this change, and they must be carefully considered. This article explores the numerous privacy and security flaws, such as data breaches, illegal access, and compliance issues, that are inherent to databases hosted on the cloud. This article takes a look at the cloud from the user and provider points of view, and it discusses the main techniques and solutions that may be used to lessen the impact of these risks. The report argues for a multi-pronged strategy to protect sensitive data kept in the cloud, including strong encryption, access control methods, data governance frameworks, and user awareness training. In addition, the article delves into how regulations like GDPR and HIPAA affect database administration in the cloud. The document lists recommended practices for protecting personal information within the bounds of the law, drawing attention to the necessity of taking preventative actions to comply with these rules. This article seeks to offer useful insights to individuals and organisations who depend on cloud-based database management systems by critically analysing current difficulties and exploring appropriate solutions. The document enables stakeholders to harness the advantages of the cloud while protecting their precious data by stressing the significance of a thorough security and privacy plan.

title: World's First 5G-Based Intercontinental Remote Robotic Surgery: Framework Development for End-to-End Management Ensuring Medical Quality and Safety
affiliations: Fujian Medical University - Department of Endocrinology and Fujian Medical University - Fujian Provincial Hospital

detail.title: World's First 5G-Based Intercontinental Remote Robotic Surgery: Framework Development for End-to-End Management Ensuring Medical Quality and Safety
detail.abstract: With the advancement and development of technologies such as robot-assisted surgery, computer-assisted surgical systems, 5G network transmission, and artificial intelligence (AI), coupled with the growing demand from patients for high-quality medical services, telesurgery has transcended spatial limitations. It can swiftly deliver top-tier surgical expertise to any area within communication coverage, significantly enhancing the efficiency of medical services. In July 2025, the urology team at Fuzhou University Affiliated Provincial Hospital, a tertiary care institution, in collaboration with experts from Beijing and France, successfully performed the world's first remote robotic-assisted surgery over a network distance of 15,000 kilometers (9,400 kilometers in a straight line). Utilizing a 5G ultra-remote domestic surgical robot, they performed the resection and anastomosis of the upper segment of the left ureter. This groundbreaking procedure was live-streamed globally during the International Society of Robotic Surgery (SRS) Annual Meeting, marking it as the world's first cross-continental three-console robot-assisted 5G ultra-telesurgery. To establish a management system that aligns with the advancement of emerging medical technologies, this paper employs SWOT analysis to explore a comprehensive control model for telesurgery throughout all phases: before, during, and after the operation. The focus is on medical quality and safety while constructing a management framework centered on patient safety. This framework is supported by technological advancements and reinforced by systematic processes. Ultimately, this lays a solid foundation for the widespread application of telesurgery.

title: Exploring Data Analytics on Open-Source Software Repositories: A Review of Development Activities and Tools for Mining Logs
affiliations: University of Wollongong in Dubai

detail.title: Exploring Data Analytics on Open-Source Software Repositories: A Review of Development Activities and Tools for Mining Logs
detail.abstract: The rapid evolution of software development practices, coupled with the increasing prominence of open-source software (OSS) projects, has positioned versioning systems as invaluable repositories of information for analysis. This paper delves into the factors that shape software development activities by examining documented methodologies and tools used to mine and analyze OSS repositories. Through a detailed review of approaches addressing developer contributions, code modifications, and collaborative workflows, we identify key influences on productivity, code quality. Our exploration includes an analysis of analytics techniques and tools, such as CVSSearch and CVSAnalY, that facilitate a deeper understanding of developer behaviour and project evolution.

title: The Role of Social Media in Fostering Resilient Disaster Management
affiliations: affiliation not provided to SSRN and affiliation not provided to SSRN

detail.title: The Role of Social Media in Fostering Resilient Disaster Management
detail.abstract: Disasters are pivotal moments of societal instability, which, in addition to causing physical damage and threatening life, also disrupt information flow. Authorities implementing disaster management processes inevitably make decisions based on incomplete situational awareness. This study examines social media’s potential to enhance resilient disaster management by supporting knowledge formation and collective action. We adopt a mixed-methods approach with multiple data, consisting of documents, interviews and workshop material. Our findings indicate that social media enables means to support resilience strengthening mechanisms in disaster management in each temporal phase of disasters. Effective utilization of social media requires proactive strategic planning, stronger utilization of its potential for reciprocity, and recognizing it as a tool for learning and development. Social media can foster resilient disaster management by providing a platform for increasing awareness and motivation, facilitating proactive information gathering, supporting coordination and utilization of citizen knowledge, strengthening trust and the sense of security, and collecting feedback.

title: Textual and AI-based Analysis of Climate Disclosures: Evidence from the European Energy Sector
affiliations: Excelia Business School

detail.title: Textual and AI-based Analysis of Climate Disclosures: Evidence from the European Energy Sector
detail.abstract: As European companies face increasing pressure to align with sustainability reporting frameworks, recent analyses of corporate disclosures reveal uneven quality, with gaps in clarity, structure, and thematic integration. This paper examines the textual structure of climaterelated financial disclosures in the European energy sector, focusing on their alignment with the Task Force on Climate-Related Financial Disclosures (TCFD) recommendations on governance, strategy, risk management, and metrics and targets. The analysis combines four layers: lexicometric diagnostics to assess readability and structure; AI-based BERT models to evaluate alignment; topic modeling to explore thematic organisation; and panel regressions to identify structural, financial, and cultural drivers. Results show that firms prioritize metrics and strategy over governance and risk management. Shorter, focused language improves alignment with risk disclosures, while lexical variety supports governance and strategy. Thematic analysis reveals fragmented climate narratives, suggesting limited maturity in integration. Regression results highlight that board gender diversity, ownership structure, ESG scores, EU taxonomy-aligned revenues, and cultural orientation are key drivers of TCFD alignment. These alignments are material, as each is significantly linked to firm valuation, indicating investors respond to depth and specificity of disclosures. Findings advance understanding of narrative climate disclosures and offer practical insights for assurance, benchmarking, and sustainability analysis.

title: Experimental Evidence on Systematic Misperceptions About Non-Selfish Behaviors
affiliations: Monash University, affiliation not provided to SSRN, Universidad Autonoma de Madrid, Universidad Autonoma de Madrid and Spanish Council for Scientific Research (CSIC)

detail.title: Experimental Evidence on Systematic Misperceptions About Non-Selfish Behaviors
detail.abstract: We investigate misperceptions regarding non-selfish behavior focusing on the extent to which second-party punishment and reward are either underestimated or overestimated. Our study encompasses various games and treatments that span a wide array of decision environments, including different (i) trade-offs (e.g., Pareto vs. non-Pareto dominated, socially efficient vs. inefficient), (ii) motives for non-selfish behavior (e.g., inequity aversion, reciprocity), (iii) costs associated with punishing and rewarding, (iv) incentives for belief accuracy, and (v) the number of allocations in a given game. Our findings reveal a consistent underestimation of rewards at both the aggregate and individual levels. This suggests that individuals harbor pessimistic perceptions or "mental models" regarding human rewarding behavior, regardless of the decision environment and incentives at play. In contrast, beliefs concerning punishment tend to be more accurate, indicating that participants anticipate altruistic punishment within our experimental setup. Additionally, we observe that women, economists, and individuals with stronger religious affiliations tend to underestimate rewards.

title: Political Connections and Access to Finance for SMEs: The Role of Discouraged Borrowers
affiliations: Xiamen University - School of Management and Durham University

detail.title: Political Connections and Access to Finance for SMEs: The Role of Discouraged Borrowers

keywords.keywords: Political connections; Bank lending; Credit access; Discouraged Borrowers; SMEs

detail.abstract: Using a sample of 6,399 SMEs across 22 transition countries, we show that firms with political connections are 6% less likely to be credit constrained compared to firms without political connections. This improved access to credit is mainly driven by the fact that politically connected SMEs are less likely to be discouraged from seeking external debt financing, rather than because of the preferential lending they receive from banks. This credit encouragement effect is stronger in countries with weaker formal institutions, among firms facing lower agency costs, and is linked to higher firm productivity. Our findings have important implications for policies targeting to improve credit access for SMEs.

title: Knowledgeable Partisans and Inflation Expectations
affiliations: Carleton College and Carleton College - Department of Economics

detail.title: Knowledgeable Partisans and Inflation Expectations

declarations.declarationOfInterest: Both authors declare they have no relevant personal or financial interests that affected this study.
declarations.funderStatement: The data in this survey is from a module of the 2024 Cooperative Election Study, which received support from the National Science Foundation (award number \# 2342506).

detail.abstract: Using a nationally representative survey from the 2024 United States presidential election, we investigate the role knowledge plays in the difference between inflation expectations of Republicans and Democrats. Unconditionally, Republicans' average inflation forecast was nearly 3% higher than Democrats; they also reported higher inflation in the past year (3.5%) and higher expectations in the long run (2.0%). Conditioning on their beliefs about the future and their long-run forecasts reduces the pure partisan gap in inflation forecasts by two thirds. The gap between Democrats and Republicans is largest for partisans who are the most knowledgeable about politics. Greater numeracy appears to exacerbate the partisan gap, while greater economic knowledge mitigates it. The differential role of partisan and economic knowledge are consistent with a model where respondents' survey responses balance objective forecasts with affective motives.
