title: Climate Change Risk and the Cost of Mortgage Credit
affiliations: Durham University, University of Zurich - Department Finance, Xiamen University - School of Management and University of Edinburgh - Business School

detail.title: Climate Change Risk and the Cost of Mortgage Credit

publicationDetails.detailsText: Swiss Finance Institute Research Paper No. 20-97
publicationDetails.journalName: Swiss Finance Institute Research Paper Series

detail.abstract: We show that lenders charge higher interest rates for mortgages on properties exposed to a greater risk of sea level rise (SLR). This SLR premium is not evident in short-term loans and is not related to borrowers’ short-term realized default or creditworthiness. Further, the SLR premium is smaller when the consequences of climate change are less salient and in areas with more climate change deniers. Overall, our results suggest that mortgage lenders view the risk of SLR as a long term risk, and that attention and beliefs are potential barriers through which SLR risk is priced in residential mortgage markets.

title: Measuring Employers’ Demand for Personality Traits in Job Ads
affiliations: University of Alberta and University of Alberta - Department of Economics

detail.title: Measuring Employers’ Demand for Personality Traits in Job Ads
detail.abstract: We propose measures of employers’ demands for personality traits from job ads based on employers' use of trait-descriptive terms from the psychology literature on personality. Identifying personality demands in job ads requires addressing challenges such as the prevalence of false positives. We demonstrate that as many as half of all instances of trait descriptive terms in job ads are false positives in the sense that they do not refer to workers' personalities. The presence of false negatives is less problematic. After eliminating false positives, we validate that our measures capture employers' demand for personality traits by showing that, at the occupation level, our measures are correlated with the traits of individuals in those occupations for all traits except emotional stability. In our sample of job ads, personality trait demands are as prevalent in ads as requirements for human capital such as education and work experience. Consistent with evidence on the importance of social skills in the labor market, extroversion is the trait most commonly sought by employers, but a substantial fraction of ads also indicate demand for conscientiousness, openness, and agreeableness.

title: Extreme Weather and Indigenous Peoples: Impacts on Business Activity
affiliations: University of California, Davis - Graduate School of Management, Victoria University of Wellington - Te Herenga Waka - School of Accounting and Commercial Law and University of Otago

detail.title: Extreme Weather and Indigenous Peoples: Impacts on Business Activity
detail.abstract: Whereas numerous studies document the impacts of climate change on business activity, evidence on how it aOects the people running those businesses-who may come from diverse socioeconomic backgrounds-remains mixed and not well understood. This study investigates the economic impact of extreme weather events (EWEs) on business activity in New Zealand, with a focus on businesses in Māori and non-Māori communities. Using a novel combination of datasets, including up to 15 years of monthly business sales, meteorological data, demographic statistics, and ancestral geographic markers, we examine how extreme hot and cold temperature, rainfall, and wind events influence sales at the micro level, across over 2,000 statistical area units (SA2s). Extreme heat EWEs significantly reduce business sales, with an average monthly decline of 1.77% and an average annual loss per business unit of $US 23,390 (standard deviation $US 19,189). This eOect follows a non-linear, hump-shaped pattern, intensifying above 23°C. However, despite well documented socioeconomic disparities, Māori and non-Māori populations exhibit virtually identical business responses to EWEs after controlling for location and socioeconomic disparities. This reveals that Indigenous identification alone does not shape business vulnerability to climate-related disruptions. Our findings provide new insights into climate adaptation, Indigenous economic resilience, and sustainable development. They underscore the need for targeted climate policies that address broad business vulnerabilities, rather than directing resources solely based on ethnic or cultural characteristics.*

title: An Empirical Study of Bid Protests by Disappointed Tenderers in U.S. States
affiliations: Independent

detail.title: An Empirical Study of Bid Protests by Disappointed Tenderers in U.S. States

keywords: World Trade Organization Government Procurement Agreement

detail.abstract: Trade negotiators have long sought increased access to US subcentral procurement. Coverage of trade agreements is a quantitative component of that effort; there is also a qualitative component. If market access is to be of any value, it must be meaningful. And meaningful access must entail the availability of remedies for disappointed suppliers such as those mandated by the Agreement on Government Procurement. Until now little effort has been made to assess the utilization of such procedures at the subcentral level. This article fills that gap. It assembles data on bid protest rates for 2 7 of the 3 7 signatory states as well as 9 of the 13 non-signatory states. Litigation in both groups is robust. On average, protests in the United States are at least as common at the state level as at the federal level. Apart from the inherent value of such data, one would hope that awareness that protests are common at the state level would foster confidence among foreign suppliers and thus encourage greater participation from abroad.

title: Untwisting the Security of Undersea Internet Cables
affiliations: Seton Hall Law School

detail.title: Untwisting the Security of Undersea Internet Cables
detail.abstract: Nearly all the intercontinental Internet traffic around the world depends on a relative handful of undersea cables. Without them, the Internet as we know it would not exist.  These undersea cables are under attack. These attacks raise challenging issues relating to the international law of the sea and the laws of armed conflict.  This article presents the most comprehensive analysis of these issues in the literature. It is also the only article to conceive of the problem not only as one of international law but also as one of internet governance. The Internet’s physical core entwines the globe and complicates Westphalian international law paradigms. The influence of a small number of large multinational companies over the physical core makes the problem even more confounding. It will take multiple, subtly calibrated policy interventions to make some progress on this knotty problem consistent with sound principles of Internet governance.

title: Governance: Productivity and Friction
affiliations: James Cook University - College of Business, Law and Governance,

detail.title: Governance: Productivity and Friction

keywords: Governance frictionPolycentric governance Mission-oriented investment Public sector capability Institutional design Reflexive governance Legitimacy metrics Co-governance Adaptive governance Distributed decision-making

detail.abstract: Australia's labour productivity growth has stalled, with output per hour worked falling 3.5 per cent in 2022-23, the sharpest decline in six decades. In response, the Future Made in Australia Act 2024 (FMIA) commits $22.7 billion to mission-driven investment in critical minerals, clean energy, sovereign manufacturing, and emerging technologies. The policy vision is strategically sound, but history shows that investment alone does not guarantee capability gains. Past initiatives have been slowed, diluted, or derailed by governance friction, structural, procedural, relational, and adaptive weaknesses that erode legitimacy, stall delivery, and limit long-term impact. Without reform, FMIA risks repeating the experience of underperforming programs such as the Northern Australia Infrastructure Facility, rather than replicating agile, trusted models like the Clean Energy Finance Corporation. Four governance frictions are most likely to undermine FMIA's ambitions: 1. Structural-Centralised decision-making that sidelines regional and sector-specific priorities. 2. Procedural-Output-driven, contractual funding models that discourage long-term capability-building. 3. Relational-Weak stakeholder trust due to opaque governance processes. 4. Adaptive-Limited mechanisms for regular review and course correction.

title: Agency Cost and Debt Financing: Evidence from Developing Countries
affiliations: University of Texas Rio Grande Valley (UTRGV) (Formerly University of Texas-Pan American) - College of Business and Entrepreneurship, University of Texas Rio Grande Valley and Southern Utah University

detail.title: Agency Cost and Debt Financing: Evidence from Developing Countries
detail.abstract: In this paper, we investigate the valuation effect of debt financing in the context of corporate agency problems. Utilizing debt financing announcements obtained from the news search in 19 emerging markets, we find that the announcement returns on new debts are positively associated with corporate agency costs measured by the ownership held by controlling shareholders who are affiliated with management and family members. These results are particularly strong in companies lacking other corporate governance mechanisms. We also identify that creditors' monitoring serves as a channel for value creation by efficient investments in M&As. Overall, our results shed light on the disciplinary role of creditors in the emerging markets, where extreme agency problems between controlling and non-controlling shareholders are prevalent.

title: International Credit Cycles
affiliations: Tsinghua University - Tsinghua University School of Economics and Management, Fudan University - School of Economics and Shanghai University of Finance and Economics - School of Economics

detail.title: International Credit Cycles
detail.abstract: We develop a two-country model to study a novel transmission mechanism for financial crises through cross-border capital flows. In our model, an excessive credit expansion in one country exacerbates the moral hazard problem in its interbank market, leading to a market collapse and subsequent capital flight. Such inflows into the second country have nonmonotonic effects on its economy. While raising total credit for production, capital inflows exacerbate credit misallocation by tightening endogenous borrowing constraints for high-productivity agents. Sufficiently large inflows may trigger a collapse in the recipient country's interbank market, leading to a discontinuous welfare loss. We show that optimal policy responses depend on the magnitude and composition (debt versus FDI) of capital inflows.  In the dynamic model, we characterize various patterns of international financial risk contagion and endogenous boom-bust credit cycles in the global economy. The model provides a theoretical foundation for the empirical finding that surges in capital inflows, not just sudden stops, are potent predictors of banking crises.

title: Estimating the Information Component in Switching Costs: A Structural Approach
affiliations: University of Virginia, ESE Business School and Universidad Adolfo Ibáñez

detail.title: Estimating the Information Component in Switching Costs: A Structural Approach
detail.abstract: We exploit a regulatory reform in Chile to quantify the role of information frictions in consumer credit markets. The reform mandated a standardized, simple disclosure sheet for loan contract terms, facilitating comparison across lenders. Using administrative, loan-level data covering the universe of bank-originated credit, we document a 10% increase in price sensitivity from borrower switching behavior following the reform. Embedding this estimate into a dynamic structural model incorporating borrower search and bank pricing responses, we simulate long-run market equilibrium effects. We find that improved consumer search efficiency lowers average interest rates by 180 basis points increases borrower welfare by 15%.

title: The Intergenerational Persistence of Intimate Partner Violence
affiliations: University of Galway

detail.title: The Intergenerational Persistence of Intimate Partner Violence
detail.abstract: This study quantifies the intergenerational persistence of intimate partner violence (IPV) in 55 low- and middle-income countries. Daughters of victims are 59-88% more likely to experience emotional, physical or sexual IPV. Persistence is partly explained by the intergenerational transmission of attitudes: Daughters of victims have more accepting attitudes toward IPV and marry men who are also more accepting, both of which predict the incidence of IPV. This greater acceptance among daughters of victims reflects the mother-to-daughter transmission of attitudes to IPV. Exploiting within-country, over-time variation, I show that improvements in gender equality and reductions in the societal acceptance of IPV are associated with reductions in both the incidence and persistence of IPV.

title: Judicial Fairness Perception and Corporate Innovation: Evidence from Entrepreneur Survey in China
affiliations: Central University of Finance and Economics (CUFE) - School of Finance, Central University of Finance and Economics (CUFE) - School of Finance and Shenzhen University

detail.title: Judicial Fairness Perception and Corporate Innovation: Evidence from Entrepreneur Survey in China
detail.abstract: This study examines the impact of judicial fairness perception on corporate innovation among small and medium-sized enterprises (SMEs) in China, utilizing data from the 2018 Enterprise Survey for Innovation and Entrepreneurship (ESIEC). Our findings reveal a robust positive relationship between higher levels of judicial fairness perception and increased innovation activities within SMEs. Notably, this effect is more pronounced in enterprises led by less-educated entrepreneurs, located in regions with weaker intellectual property protection, or with lower reliance on government support. We identify improved contract enforcement, enhanced policy effectiveness, and increased innovation investment as key mechanisms driving this relationship. These results suggest that judicial reforms to increase fairness can significantly foster innovation, particularly in resource-constrained SMEs in emerging economies.

title: ORTA ASYA TÜRK DEVLETLERİNİN ELEKTRİK İHRACATININ KARŞILAŞTIRMALI ÜSTÜNLÜĞÜ VE REKABET GÜCÜ ANALİZİ (COMPARATIVE ADVANTAGE AND COMPETITIVENESS ANALYSIS OF ELECTRICITY EXPORTS OF CENTRAL ASIAN TURKIC STATES)
affiliations: Bağımsız Araştırmacı and Sumgait State University

detail.title: ORTA ASYA TÜRK DEVLETLERİNİN ELEKTRİK İHRACATININ KARŞILAŞTIRMALI ÜSTÜNLÜĞÜ VE REKABET GÜCÜ ANALİZİ (COMPARATIVE ADVANTAGE AND COMPETITIVENESS ANALYSIS OF ELECTRICITY EXPORTS OF CENTRAL ASIAN TURKIC STATES)
detail.abstract:
Turkish abstract: Yeşil enerji üretiminin artırılması karbon emisyonlarının azaltılmasını sağlayarak sadece çevresel değil, aynı zamanda ekonomik ve stratejik bir avantaja dönüşmektedir. Bu konularda mevcut çalışmalar da yapılmıştır. Bu makalede, söz konusu ülkelerin 2017-2023 yılları arasındaki elektrik ihracatı incelenmekte ve ticaret dengesi, açıklanmış karşılaştırmalı üstünlük, göreli ticaret avantajı, göreli ihracat avantajı ve göreli ithalat avantajı endeksleri kullanılarak ampirik analizler yapılmaktadır. Kullanılan veri kaynağı Uluslararası Ticaret Merkezi’dir. Yapılan araştırma sonuçları, enerji sektöründe çeşitlendirmenin ve yenilenebilir enerji kaynaklarının geliştirilmesinin belirtilen ülkeler açısından stratejik öneme sahip olduğunu göstermektedir. Kazakistan, Türkmenistan ve Özbekistan'da yeşil kaynaklardan elektrik üretiminin artırılması, mevcut pazarlardan daha geniş pazarlara erişim imkânı yaratıyor. Yapılan analiz sonucunda Özbekistan ve Türkmenistan’ın rekabet avantajına sahip olduğu ortaya çıktı. Sonuçlar, yeşil enerji üretiminin artırılmasının söz konusu ülkelerin bölgesel ve küresel pazarlardaki konumlarını güçlendirebileceğini ve elektrik ihracatında sürdürülebilirliği sağlayabileceğini göstermektedir. 

English abstract: Increasing green energy production is not only an environmental, but also an economic and strategic advantage by reducing carbon emissions. Current studies have been carried out on these topics. In this article, the electricity exports of the mentioned countries between 2017-2023 are analyzed and empirical analyzes are made using the indices of trade balance, revealed comparative advantage, relative trade advantage, relative export advantage and relative import advantage. The data source used is the International Trade Center. The results of the research show that diversification in the energy sector and the development of renewable energy sources are of strategic importance for the mentioned countries. Increasing the production of electricity from green sources in Kazakhstan, Turkmenistan and Uzbekistan creates the opportunity to access wider markets than the existing ones. As a result of the analysis, it was revealed that Uzbekistan and Turkmenistan have a competitive advantage. The results show that increasing the production of green energy can strengthen the position of the countries in question in the regional and global markets and ensure the sustainability of electricity exports.

title: ESG as a Mitigator of Oil Volatility Risk
affiliations: University of Essex - Essex Business School, Audencia Business School, University of Essex - Essex Business School and Audencia Business School

detail.title: ESG as a Mitigator of Oil Volatility Risk
detail.abstract: ESG activities are a forward-looking measure to prevent risks from negative externalities. Linking ESG scores with the crude oil market, we assess their mitigating effect on returns during periods of rising oil price volatility. We examine the interplay between ESG scores and crude oil volatility’s impact on returns. Interestingly, this interaction transforms ESG into an insurance-like hedge, protecting returns as volatility increases. Notably, we identify a pivotal turning point at relatively low volatility levels. Below this threshold, ESG activities lack effectiveness, but when volatility surpasses it, their hedging power becomes pronounced. This effect intensifies as volatility rises, rewarding ESG leaders more significantly. Our sectoral and quantile analyses corroborate these findings. Overall, our findings support the role of ESG activities as a “safe haven” in times of financial turmoil, focusing its contribution to the interplay between ESG and oil volatility on periods of heightened uncertainty in the crude oil market.

reference: Boston Univ. School of Law Research Paper No. 25-25
title: Is R&D Rivalry Slowing the Growth of Productive Firms?
affiliations: Singapore Management University, Technology & Policy Research Initiative, BU School of Law and Northeastern University (USA) - D’Amore-McKim School of Business

detail.title: Is R&D Rivalry Slowing the Growth of Productive Firms?

publicationDetails.detailsText: Boston Univ. School of Law Research Paper No. 25-25
publicationDetails.journalName: Boston University School of Law Research Paper Series

detail.abstract: The reallocation of jobs to more productive firms is a substantial component of aggregate productivity growth, yet job reallocation rates have declined substantially in the United States. This paper explores the hypothesis that greater technological rivalry has exacerbated adjustment costs, slowing reallocation. Using microdata at the US Census and estimates of technological rivalry in firm growth regressions, we find that technological rivalry slows firm responses to productivity shocks. Firms do not expand as rapidly in the face of higher obsolescence risk. Estimating counterfactual firm growth from 1997-2018, we find that growing technological rivalry accounts for most of the decline in job reallocation. Counterintuitively, rising technological rivalry may slow reallocation, dampening aggregate productivity growth.

title: Supply Shocks and Inflation: Timely Insights from Financial Markets
affiliations: Bank of Italy, European Central Bank (ECB) and European Central Bank (ECB)

detail.title: Supply Shocks and Inflation: Timely Insights from Financial Markets
detail.abstract: We introduce a mixed-frequency model that identifies the impact of supply shocks on inflation in the United States in real time. The model decomposes weekly movements in inflation-linked swap rates—market-based inflation expectations—and isolates three supply shocks: global value chain disruptions, energy supply shocks, and domestic supply constraints, separating them from demand-driven factors. We show how these shocks contributed to a post-Covid feedback loop that intensified inflation. By linking weekly shocks to monthly inflation components up to the industry level, we find that global value chain disruptions generate the most persistent and broad-based price pressures, while energy and domestic supply shocks tend to produce more transitory effects, as their narrower inflationary impact is more easily offset by demand-dampening, contractionary forces. Our model captures these various supply-side dynamics effectively and offers timely insights to support a more responsive monetary policy.

title: Collateral and Credit
affiliations: KU Leuven - Faculty of Business and Economics (FEB), Tilburg University - Department of Finance, National Bank of Belgium - Research Department, European Central Bank (ECB) and KU Leuven - Department of Accountancy, Finance and Insurance (AFI)

detail.title: Collateral and Credit
detail.abstract: This paper studies the role of collateral using the euro area corporate credit registry, Ana-Credit. We document key facts about the importance, distribution, and composition of collateral, including its presence, types, and values. On average, 70% of credit amounts are collateralized. Real estate and financial assets are the most pledged, while physical movable assets and other intangible assets are less present. In addition, we show that the aggregate collateral value pledged to the banking sector is substantial, driven mainly by real estate in most countries. For the first time, we examine the collateral channel in bank credit using the actual value of individual collateral. By exploiting within-firm and within-bank variations for newly issued secured loans, we find that the elasticity of collateral value to loan commitment amounts is around 0.7-0.8. This collateral value elasticity exhibits substantial country and time heterogeneity, which can be explained by legal, financial, and macro conditions.

title: Assessing Uncertainty in Stock Returns: A Gaussian Mixture Distribution-Based Method
affiliations: Tsinghua University - Tsinghua Shenzhen International Graduate School, affiliation not provided to SSRN, affiliation not provided to SSRN, Tsinghua University, Peng Cheng National Laboratory and Tsinghua University

detail.title: Assessing Uncertainty in Stock Returns: A Gaussian Mixture Distribution-Based Method
detail.abstract: This study seeks to advance the understanding and prediction of stock market return uncertainty through the application of advanced deep learning techniques. We introduce a novel deep learning model that utilizes a Gaussian mixture distribution to capture the complex, time-varying nature of asset return distributions in the Chinese stock market. By incorporating the Gaussian mixture distribution, our approach effectively characterizes short-term fluctuations and non-traditional features of stock returns—such as skewness and heavy tails—that are often overlooked by traditional models. Compared to GARCH models and their variants, our method demonstrates superior performance in volatility estimation, particularly during periods of heightened market volatility. It provides more accurate volatility forecasts and offers unique risk insights for different assets, thereby deepening the understanding of return uncertainty. Additionally, we propose a novel use of Code embedding which utilizes a bag-of-words approach to train hidden representations of stock codes and transforms the uncertainty attributes of stocks into high-dimensional vectors. These vectors are subsequently reduced to two dimensions, allowing the observation of similarity among different stocks. This visualization facilitates the identification of asset clusters with similar risk profiles, offering valuable insights for portfolio management and risk mitigation. Since we predict the uncertainty of returns by estimating their latent distribution, it is challenging to evaluate the return distribution when the true distribution is unobservable. However, we can measure it through the CRPS (Continuous Ranked Probability Score) to assess how well the predicted distribution matches the true returns, and through MSE (Mean Squared Error) and QLIKE (quasi-likelihood) metrics to evaluate the error between the volatility level of the predicted distribution and proxy measures of true volatility. The results highlight the robustness and predictive accuracy of our approach, suggesting that it significantly improves volatility forecasting and enhances the practical utility of risk modeling in financial markets. In summary, we assess return uncertainty at each timestep, performing extensive experiments across Chinese equities and measuring uncertainty similarities among stocks. With the Transformer-based model enhanced by stock ticker embeddings, our framework outputs the Gaussian mixture distribution to characterize the return uncertainty, offering a new approach to study return volatility.

title: The Gospel of Wealth for African Americans: A 120-Hour Course for Black Business Success
affiliations: Independent

detail.title: The Gospel of Wealth for African Americans: A 120-Hour Course for Black Business Success

contentType.other: An issue of first impression in business education addressing wealth inequality

detail.abstract: This paper introduces "The Gospel of Wealth for African Americans," a 120-hour free online business curriculum designed to close the racial wealth gap. Drawing inspiration from Carnegie's foundational text, this course reframes wealth-building for the Black community through structured modules on business planning, tax strategies, credit building, reinvestment, and community economics. By integrating historical analysis, modern financial tools, and culturally grounded frameworks, this program provides actionable pathways for Black entrepreneurs to create and sustain intergenerational wealth.

title: The Power Behind the Numbers: The Use and Configuration of Performance Indicators as an Organizational Control Strategy
affiliations: affiliation not provided to SSRN and affiliation not provided to SSRN

detail.title: The Power Behind the Numbers: The Use and Configuration of Performance Indicators as an Organizational Control Strategy
detail.abstract: The study begins with the goal of analyzing how the use and configuration of performance indicators strengthen and reproduce power. In light of the foregoing, exploratory research was conducted through a case study and qualitative methods, based on interviews with 14 managers from the assistive and administrative areas of a hospital setting, working in tactical and strategic roles. In addition to the interview script, observations and document analysis were performed, aiming at data triangulation. The interviews were transcribed and coded using the Nvivo 12® software, and the used data analysis technique was discourse analysis. The results revealed that the hospital’s performance indicators are used and configured to strengthen and reproduce power in the hospital, with the assistive area, through the quality sector, being the one that most denotes power in the field and is responsible for the indicators. Moreover, the use of performance indicators, such as the so-called black list and the loss list, is one of the greatest examples of control, domination, and reproduction of power concerning the activities of managers in the hospital. For this reason, they generate tension and concern among those responsible for filling out the indicators. Accordingly, although the managers may be apprehensive about such performance indicators and their disclosure, they understand and emphasize their importance for the hospital. This study advances with respect to theory by demonstrating the use of non-financial indicators as a strategic tool in the articulation of power relations.

title: Sdface-Gan: Lightweight 3d-Aware Generative Adversarial Network for Facial Image and Geometry Synthesis
affiliations: Nanchang University, Nanchang University, Nanchang University, Nanchang University, affiliation not provided to SSRN and Nanchang University

detail.title: Sdface-Gan: Lightweight 3d-Aware Generative Adversarial Network for Facial Image and Geometry Synthesis
detail.abstract: Multi-view facial synthesis is crucial for online rendering and 3D face reconstruction. However, current 3D-aware GAN methods lack consistency in multi-view facial synthesis, potentially leading to failures in facial 3D mesh generation. To address this, we propose SDFace-GAN, a lightweight 3D-aware GAN incorporating a NeRF-GAN and a Style-based neural up-sampler. Our NeRF-GAN constructs a signed distance fields to achieve high-precision 3D facial mesh, while the Style-based neural up-sampler employs self-supervised methods to reduce image inconsistency. Our approach enables the generation of high-quality 3D models and outperforms benchmark methods, demonstrating a 3% improvement in the FID metric. SDFace-GAN achieves state-of-the-art results in synthesizing multi-view images from unsupervised 2D data on FFHQ and CelebA-HQ datasets.Our code is publicly available at: https://github.com/YangYeTian/SDFace-GAN.

title: Zidar: Zero-Inflated Deep Autoregressive Model for Intermittent Time Series Forecasting
affiliations: affiliation not provided to SSRN, affiliation not provided to SSRN, affiliation not provided to SSRN, affiliation not provided to SSRN and affiliation not provided to SSRN

detail.title: Zidar: Zero-Inflated Deep Autoregressive Model for Intermittent Time Series Forecasting
detail.abstract: Time series forecasting plays a crucial role in various fields, and accurately predicting sales data, especially for commodities in B2B transactions, brings significant economic benefits. However, intermittent time series, characterized by sparse non-zero values, irregular zeros, and distinct individual patterns, pose unique challenges. Traditional time series analysis techniques and most deep neural networks struggle with zero-inflated data, often leading to inaccurate predictions. In this paper, we propose the Zero-Inflated Deep AutoRegressive (ZIDAR) model to address these issues. Our model constructs a sophisticated representation architecture by combining recurrent neural networks (RNNs) and temporal convolutional networks (TCNs), which captures temporal relationships in historical data and improves the representation of zeros by replacing them with weighted quantiles. We also introduce a novel loss function, the negative likelihood of a zero-inflated mixture of Gaussian densities, enabling balanced prediction of non-zero and zero values. In addition, two practical prediction methods are provided for intermittent time series. Experimental results demonstrate that the ZIDAR model outperforms existing methods, offering a more effective solution for intermittent time series forecasting and providing valuable insights for supply chain.

title: Predicting Serial Credit Rating Downgrades
affiliations: affiliation not provided to SSRN, University of Western Australia and The University of Western Australia - Department of Accounting and Finance

detail.title: Predicting Serial Credit Rating Downgrades
detail.abstract: This paper examines the predictability of sequential credit rating downgrades under the through-the-cycle methodology used by credit rating agencies. While the lagging nature of ratings is well documented, we use a dataset of 28,847 firm-year observations for North American corporates to show that interim ratings assigned during downgrade sequences systematically understate credit risk relative to non-downgraded peers with the same rating. This understatement enables accurate prediction of further downgrades, with machine learning models achieving up to 75% accuracy. The findings have practical relevance for investors and risk managers seeking to anticipate formal rating actions before they occur.

title: Drought, Land Ownership and Labor Reallocation Evidence from India
affiliations: James Madison University - Economics Program

detail.title: Drought, Land Ownership and Labor Reallocation Evidence from India
detail.abstract: Labor reallocation represents a potentially important channel for rural households to adapt to climate change. Yet very little has been documented about barriers to this important adaptation strategy. Exploiting temporal and spatial variation in drought, characterized by low precipitation levels, in India, I find drought reduces the share of agriculture labor hours by 3.6%. Reductions are driven by households not owning land. Motivated by these facts, I develop a model of labor allocation across agriculture and non-agriculture sectors to analyze how droughts influence structural transformation. Results suggest that projected increases in the spatial extent of droughts will induce landowning households to allocate more labor to agriculture due to cultural norms and limited markets for land whereas induce landless households to reduce their agricultural labor. The net effect is a 1% reduction in total agricultural labor supply. This implies that 2.5 million individuals will leave agriculture. I then use the model to run policy counterfactual regarding how projected climate change could influence the cost to the government of achieving its stated target of increasing the manufacturing share of GDP to 25% by 2035. Projected climate change would require the government to subsidize non-agriculture wages more relative to current status quo climate conditions due to the presence of land market frictions.

title: On the Welfare Effects of Compatibility with Hotelling Competition
affiliations: Università degli Studi di Milano-Bicocca - Department of Economics, Management and Statistics (DEMS)

detail.title: On the Welfare Effects of Compatibility with Hotelling Competition
detail.abstract: In a setting with Hotelling differentiation and (weak) network effects, when the market is already covered duopoly adoption of compatibility leads to anti-competitive effects and tends to be welfare excessive. We show that the latter result is reversed if the market is not assumed to be covered even under incompatibility (a condition which depends on the value of the intrinsic/stand-alone benefits).

title: Optimization of Well Design to Improve the Productivity of Heavy Oil in Extreme Cold Region
affiliations: Chonnam National University and Chonnam National University

detail.title: Optimization of Well Design to Improve the Productivity of Heavy Oil in Extreme Cold Region
detail.abstract: This study aims to optimize well design through pressurization, electrical heating, and insulation to enhance the productivity of high-viscosity oil in the Milne Point area on the North Slope of Alaska. A production well and fluid model was developed using PIPESIM, incorporating pressurization via pumps, heaters, and insulation. Productivity analysis indicated that the highest output was achieved by combining pumps and heaters with insulation. The application of vacuum-insulated tubing (VIT), characterized by low thermal conductivity, increased production by approximately 2.3 times. Subsequently, a sensitivity analysis was conducted based on the productivity results to quantify the contribution of each production method. The analysis revealed that the pump had the most significant impact on productivity, accounting for 63.1% of the overall increase. These results suggest that insulation and heaters should be installed when the pump is applied, and that VIT with low thermal conductivity is particularly effective when heaters are employed. An economic evaluation was performed using the net present value (NPV) to determine the optimal operating conditions for the production well. The findings demonstrated that installing electric submersible pumps (ESP) is essential for economically viable production. When insulation, heaters, and pumps were used in combination, the maximum NPV was 2.7 times higher than that of a well equipped with a pump alone. These results confirm that integrating multiple production enhancement methods can improve both productivity and economic performance, even when accounting for the associated investment costs.

title: Breaking Par-Value Spillovers and Systemic Risk
affiliations: affiliation not provided to SSRN and Zhongnan University of Economics and Law

detail.title: Breaking Par-Value Spillovers and Systemic Risk
detail.abstract: Based on data from wealth management products (WMPs) issued by wealth management subsidiaries of listed banks in China, and focusing on the large-scale par-value-breaking events in November 2022, this study investigates the spillover effects of par-value-breaking WMPs on the systemic risk of listed banks. The findings reveal that while these spillovers significantly reduce the systemic risk at the level of individual listed banks, they concurrently elevate systemic risk across the broader financial system. The impact varies across product types: fixed-income WMPs, medium- or low-risk products, and open-ended structures are more likely to amplify such spillover effects. In contrast, financial contagion or general risk spillovers are not the primary drivers of these effects. Instead, wealth management subsidiaries, as peripheral nodes in the banking network, play a critical role in dispersing institutional risk. Moreover, net-value-based WMPs offer a transparent mechanism for identifying, measuring, and releasing underlying asset risk, thereby helping to mitigate systemic vulnerabilities in the banking sector. These findings offer important implications for improving the regulatory framework of the wealth management market and enhancing systemic risk prevention mechanisms.

title: Local Currency Lending by Multilateral Development Banks
affiliations: affiliation not provided to SSRN and Peking University

detail.title: Local Currency Lending by Multilateral Development Banks
detail.abstract: This paper explores the prospects of local currency-denominated loans by Multilateral Development Banks (MDBs), focusing on mitigating foreign exchange and convertibility risks. It theoretically analyzes three financing strategies: (1) MDBs borrowing in hard currency and onlending through a diversified portfolio of local currencies and host countries or engaging in hedged local currency onlending; (2) issuing local currency bonds for local currency onlending; and (3) recapitalizing MDBs with hard currency to establish Local Currency Funds. Each strategy has distinct advantages and drawbacks, emphasizing the need for a case-by-case approach tailored to the macroeconomic conditions of host developing countries.

title: Do Age and Gender Affect Managers’ Careers? Evidence from the Career Paths of Movie Directors
affiliations: Yeshiva University - Syms School of Business and Yeshiva University - Syms School of Business

detail.title: Do Age and Gender Affect Managers’ Careers? Evidence from the Career Paths of Movie Directors
detail.abstract: This paper considers whether age or gender matter for managerial hiring by following the career paths of film directors. Film directors manage multi-million projects and are hired on a project-by-project basis. We gather data on directors’ background and their film projects. As expected, the success of previous film projects is the main determinant of hiring for a new film. However, we find that age matters, even though 99% of our directors are younger than 61. Age matters also for a sub-sample of directors younger than 50. We address endogeneity, consider different economic conditions, and verify that directors who dropped out of the sample did not retire.We also document that on average, only 12% of an entering cohort of new directors are women and they follow a different path than men in the entertainment industry. However, we do not find much evidence for gender bias for women who do become directors. We argue that if there is age bias in a highly visible industry, then there may be even more bias in industries with much less public scrutiny.

title: Python For Data Analytics: A Systematic Literature Review Of Tools, Techniques, And Applications
affiliations: Wright State University

detail.title: Python For Data Analytics: A Systematic Literature Review Of Tools, Techniques, And Applications
detail.abstract: In the era of big data, the ability to collect, process, and analyze data efficiently has become a vital component for decision-making across various industries. Python, as a versatile programming language, has emerged as a powerful tool for data analytics due to its extensive libraries and user-friendly nature. This systematic literature review explores Python's role in streamlining data analytics by examining its applications across various stages of the data analysis process, including data collection, cleaning, manipulation, and visualization. Key Python libraries such as NumPy, Pandas, and Matplotlib are discussed, highlighting their functionality in handling large datasets and enabling accurate and efficient analysis. Real-world examples demonstrate how Python can be applied in diverse sectors, from retail to healthcare, enhancing decision-making processes through data-driven insights. Furthermore, the limitations of Python, as well as alternative data analysis tools such as R and RapidMiner, are explored to provide a comprehensive view of Python's place in modern data analytics. The review concludes that while Python offers significant advantages in data analysis, a combination of tools may often be necessary to meet the complex demands of today's data-driven industries.

title: Geotecnologia Integrada Para Monitoramento De Pastagens No Semiárido Brasileiro
affiliations: affiliation not provided to SSRN, affiliation not provided to SSRN, affiliation not provided to SSRN, affiliation not provided to SSRN, affiliation not provided to SSRN, affiliation not provided to SSRN, affiliation not provided to SSRN, affiliation not provided to SSRN, affiliation not provided to SSRN and affiliation not provided to SSRN

detail.title: Geotecnologia Integrada Para Monitoramento De Pastagens No Semiárido Brasileiro
detail.abstract: O manejo eficiente de pastagens tem demandado estudos focados na aplicação de tecnologias remotas mais acessíveis para auxiliar os processos de tomada de decisão. Este estudo teve como objetivo investigar e monitorar a variação espaço-temporal de um sistema de pastejo rotacionado utilizando sensores RGB a bordo de aeronaves remotamente pilotadas (APRs). O experimento foi conduzido em uma pastagem de Brachiaria decumbens no Nordeste do Brasil, com períodos de pastejo de 7 dias e períodos de descanso de 28 dias, taxa de lotação de 3,2 unidades animais por hectare e área total de 2500 m² . Imagens obtidas de veículos aéreos não tripulados (VANTs) foram empregadas e sua relação com a distribuição espacial dos animais monitorados pelo Sistema de Posicionamento Global (GPS) foi analisada. Índices de vegetação como o Índice Normalizado de Diferença Verde-Vermelho (NGRDI), Índice de Folhas Verdes (GLI) e Índice de Resistência Atmosférica Visível (VARI) foram derivados de imagens de sensores RGB. O índice VARI exibiu uma faixa mais ampla de valores, variando entre 0,200 e -0,207. Fatores de precipitação e manejo influenciaram diretamente a correlação entre os índices de vegetação estudados e o índice de área foliar (IAF). Para avaliar a degradação da pastagem, o índice de degradação da pastagem (IDP) foi utilizado, revelando uma redução de 97% na vegetação entre o 1º e o 2º ciclos de pastejo, uma redução de 14% após o terceiro ciclo e uma recuperação de 1,2% após o período de descanso. A relação entre animais e variáveis ambientais (solo e vegetação) evidenciou o impacto negativo da presença excessiva de animais, resultando no aumento da resistência do solo à penetração e, consequentemente, dificultando a expansão das raízes das plantas, comprometendo a recuperação da vegetação. A análise de componentes principais foi aplicada para avaliar a correlação entre o IAF e os índices de vegetação, levando ao desenvolvimento de um modelo de regressão múltipla estimando o IAF com um R2 de 0,716. Este estudo demonstra a viabilidade do uso de tecnologias remotas para monitorar e manejar pastagens, fornecendo dados valiosos para a tomada de decisões em manejo sustentável da pecuária.

title: Input-Oriented or Output-Oriented? Optimizing Subsidy Incentives for Multi-Tier Sustainable Supply Chains
affiliations: University of South China, University of South China and University of South China

detail.title: Input-Oriented or Output-Oriented? Optimizing Subsidy Incentives for Multi-Tier Sustainable Supply Chains
detail.abstract: Designing effective subsidy mechanisms to incentivize emission reductions in multi-tier supply chains remains a critical challenge for policymakers. This study examines how governments should strategically allocate limited budgets between input-oriented subsidies and output-oriented subsidies. We model a supply chain comprising a manufacturer and multiple retailers, incorporating consumer environmental preferences and multi-tier decision-making through a dual Stackelberg game framework. Our analysis reveals: Both subsidy types improve emissions reduction and social welfare, but input-oriented subsidies drive significantly higher green investments and product sustainability; Consumer green preferences amplify policy effectiveness, acting as a market-driven multiplier for subsidy incentives; The multi-tier structure creates unique trade-offs in subsidy allocation, with input-oriented subsidies better aligning incentives across supply chain tiers. Results offer policymakers a clear rule—prioritize upfront investment subsidies—and extend theory by integrating consumer behavior and vertical channel dynamics into environmental subsidy analysis.

title: Spatiotemporal Evolution and Spatial Differentiation of Carbon Emission Intensity in China's Transportation Industry
affiliations: Wuhan University of Technology and Wuhan University of Technology

detail.title: Spatiotemporal Evolution and Spatial Differentiation of Carbon Emission Intensity in China's Transportation Industry
detail.abstract: This study investigates the spatiotemporal evolution and spatial disparities of carbon emission intensity in China's transportation industry from 2005 to 2020. A Dagum Gini coefficient is employed to assess spatial inequality and its sources from a static perspective. Kernel density estimation is applied to depict the dynamic distribution and convergence patterns. Additionally, a spatial Markov chain model is introduced to identify the locking effects of spatial disparities.The results are as follows:(1) Carbon emission intensity in the transportation industry shows a declining trend overall, but significant spatial imbalance persists across provinces. The Gini coefficient increased from 0.201 in 2005 to 0.204 in 2020, showing a fluctuating upward trend. The disparity between eastern and western regions is the primary contributor to interregional inequality, with an average Gini coefficient of 0.244. The transvariation density component contributes an average of 37.020%, representing the largest source of overall disparity.(2) A trend of convergence is observed at the national level and in the eastern and western regions, while the central region shifts from convergence to divergence. A gradient distribution structure emerges, with some provinces consistently exhibiting carbon emission intensities well above the national average.(3) Traditional Markov chain analysis reveals clear hierarchical solidification and a "club convergence" effect. The spatial Markov chain model further indicates that the state of neighboring regions significantly influences local transition probabilities, reinforcing the spatial lock-in effect of carbon emission intensity.These findings provide support for developing region-specific carbon reduction strategies to promote a green and low-carbon transformation of the transportation industry.

title: Local Government Financing Vehicles Shareholding and Corporate Earnings Management: A Discussion on the Dual Mechanisms of Resource Provision and Governance Optimization

detail.title: Local Government Financing Vehicles Shareholding and Corporate Earnings Management: A Discussion on the Dual Mechanisms of Resource Provision and Governance Optimization
detail.abstract: Our analysis of a comprehensive panel dataset covering all Shanghai and Shenzhen A-share listed firms (2009-2021) reveals that LGFVs exert significant disciplinary effects, curbing both corporate accrual-based and real earnings management. The mechanism analysis proposes a novel dual-pathway framework, demonstrating that LGFVs shareholding simultaneously enhances resource provision by reducing incentives for financial distress, and optimizes governance by strengthening monitoring capacity. Heterogeneity analysis further reveals that the governance effectiveness is particularly pronounced for LGFVs with higher administrative hierarchy or minority ownership concentration, whereas the effects are attenuated in state-owned firms and high-performing firms.

title: How Can “Zero Waste City” Construction Be Achieved Effectively? — Evidence from China's First 16 Pilot Cities
affiliations: Baotou Medical College and affiliation not provided to SSRN

detail.title: How Can “Zero Waste City” Construction Be Achieved Effectively? — Evidence from China's First 16 Pilot Cities
detail.abstract: With accelerating urbanization, cities are facing surging solid waste challenges, prompting the innovative pursuit of “Zero Waste City” initiatives. However, existing research often overlooks the multifaceted drivers and regional complexities underlying effective implementation. This study addresses these gaps by systematically examining the determinants and configuration pathways influencing the effectiveness of “Zero Waste City” construction in China, using the first 16 national pilot cities as empirical cases. Employing the entropy weight method and multi-objective decision analysis, we quantitatively evaluate the effectiveness of zero-waste efforts, and integrate six key conditional variables into a fuzzy-set qualitative comparative analysis (fsQCA) framework. Our findings reveal pronounced regional disparities in performance, driven by diverse and interacting factors—while industrial structure plays a relatively marginal role. Notably, we identify four distinct high-effectiveness pathways, such as those led by technological innovation and policy integration, that offer practical insights for scaling up zero-waste strategies nationwide. This research advances the understanding of zero-waste urban governance and provides robust, evidence-based guidance for policymakers and practitioners committed to sustainable urban transformation.

title: Life-Cycle Economic and Environmental Assessments of Pavement Overlay: Recycled vs. Conventional Sections
affiliations: Zhejiang University of Technology, Zhejiang University of Technology, Zhejiang University of Technology, Zhejiang University of Technology, Tongji University, Zhejiang University of Technology and Tongji University

detail.title: Life-Cycle Economic and Environmental Assessments of Pavement Overlay: Recycled vs. Conventional Sections
detail.abstract: The reutilization of recycled materials in road infrastructure overlay provides significant economic and environmental benefits in the construction phase. However, due to their deteriorating long-term performance, these recycled pavements may generate higher user costs and pollutant emissions in the operational phase. To comprehensively evaluate these impacts, this study conducted a life-cycle-based analysis of 20 pairs of recycled and conventional overlays based on the SPS-5 data. Statistical analysis indicated that the outcomes are significantly affected by overlay thickness and pretreatment. The life cycle cost of nearly all thin recycled overlays (51 mm) is more expensive than that of thin new overlays by 0.0415~9.41 MUSD/km. In contrast, for thick overlays (127 mm) with intensive pretreatment, 80% of recycled sections can become more cost-effective. Besides, most recycled sections demonstrate lower total carbon emissions compared to new sections, with this advantage being particularly pronounced also in the case of thick overlays and intensive pretreatment.

title: The “Age 35 Barrier” and Innovation Performance: Investigating the Age Discrimination Against Engineers and Scientists
affiliations: South China University of Technology, South China University of Technology, South China University of Technology, South China University of Technology and affiliation not provided to SSRN

detail.title: The “Age 35 Barrier” and Innovation Performance: Investigating the Age Discrimination Against Engineers and Scientists
detail.abstract: The “Age 35 Barrier” is an implicit form of workplace age discrimination, setting 35 as a critical threshold for hiring and career advancement. Using a regression discontinuity design and data from a leading professional social networking platform, this study finds no significant causal effect of turning 35 on innovation performance or the performance-income ratio among engineers and scientists. Results show an inverted U-shaped relationship between age and innovation performance, peaking at 34, and a U-shaped relationship between age and performance-income ratio, bottoming at 38–39. These findings challenge the “Age 35 Barrier” and highlight the need for more inclusive labor market.

title: Research on Ultra-Short-Term Photovoltaic Power Generation Forecasting Based on Dlinear-Lstm Model
affiliations: Zhejiang University, Zhejiang University - State Key Laboratory of Clean Energy Utilization, Zhejiang University of Water Resources and Electric Power, affiliation not provided to SSRN and affiliation not provided to SSRN

detail.title: Research on Ultra-Short-Term Photovoltaic Power Generation Forecasting Based on Dlinear-Lstm Model
detail.abstract: The power grid stability is significantly challenged by the increasing installed capacity and proportion of photovoltaic power stations,their output fluctuations which depend on the weather. As a result, highly accurate ultra - short - term forecasting of PV power generation has become extremely important. A hybrid method integrating rule - based and deep learning models is carried out in this study, with the DLinear model being used to break down time series into trend and remainder parts. After that, an LSTM model independently forecasts the outputs from the DLinear model, and then these forecasts are combined to create the DLinear - LSTM model, which is used to predict PV power generation at 5 - minute and 15 - minute intervals. At a PV power station, tests showed that the model could reach a daily average prediction accuracy of over 93%. The model shows great precision in prediction whether it is sunny or rainy. In the case of 5 - minute and 15 - minute forecasts, the model is good at seizing the trends of variation. The predicted curves are highly in line with the actual power generation patterns, showing little divergence and a high degree of correlation with the real output fluctuations. Despite the fact that cloudy weather brings more prediction difficulties because of its inherent uncertainties and thus has lower accuracy in comparison to sunny and rainy weather, the model is able to capture basic variation trends, which offers useful information for 15 - minute power generation forecasting.

detail.abstract: We propose a nonlinear framework to study the dynamic transmission of aggregate and idiosyncratic shocks to household income that exploits both macro and micro data. Our approach allows us to examine empirically the following questions: (a) How do business-cycle fluctuations modulate the persistence of heterogeneous individual histories and the risk faced by households? (b) How do aggregate and idiosyncratic shocks propagate over time for households in different macro and micro states? (c) How do these shocks shape the cost of business-cycle risk? We develop new identification and estimation techniques, and provide a detailed empirical analysis combining macro time series for the U.S. and a time series of household panels from the PSID.

title: A Double-Edged Sword: Unpacking the Dual Mechanisms of Population Aging on the Digital Economy in China
affiliations: affiliation not provided to SSRN and South China Agricultural University

detail.title: A Double-Edged Sword: Unpacking the Dual Mechanisms of Population Aging on the Digital Economy in China
detail.abstract: Population aging and digitalization are two transformative forces of the 21st century, yet their interplay remains theoretically contested. This study constructs an integrated framework that reconciles the supply-side view and the demand-side perspective, which highlights aging's suppressive effect on digital consumption. Using panel data from 31 Chinese provinces (2013–2023), we apply fixed effects, mediation-moderation analysis, and spatial Durbin models to examine the net impact of aging on digital economy development. Results reveal an overall negative effect, mainly mediated by the decline in consumption upgrading and digital adaptability. Moderation analysis shows that both formal institutions (policy intensity) and informal institutions (social sentiment) can buffer this effect. Spatial analysis further uncovers asymmetric spillovers: aging dampens local digital growth but promotes digital development in neighboring regions through labor and capital reallocation, reinforcing spatial inequality. This study contributes threefold: Our contributions are threefold: (1) Theoretically, we propose a unified framework combining opposing mechanisms and highlight the dual moderating roles of policy and social sentiment. (2) Methodologically, we identify the degradation of consumption structure as a key mediating pathway, quantify buffering effects, and reveal spatial spillovers that produce a “core–periphery” dynamic. (3) Practically, we call for a dual-pronged policy strategy—promoting elderly digital inclusion while mitigating interregional inequality through coordinated governance.

title: Perceived Risk and Risk Management Strategies in Nile Tilapia Aquaculture in Kenya
affiliations: Stanford University and Stanford University - Institute for International Studies

detail.title: Perceived Risk and Risk Management Strategies in Nile Tilapia Aquaculture in Kenya
detail.abstract: The freshwater aquaculture sector in Kenya, dominated by Nile tilapia, has rapidly expanded in recent years, but faces significant risks that threaten its sustainability, particularly among smallholder farmers. This study investigates risk perceptions and management strategies among 403 Nile tilapia farmers operating in cage and pond systems across five counties bordering Lake Victoria, using a mixed-methods approach. Data was collected using a structured survey. The analysis combines descriptive statistics, cost-efficiency assessment, factor analysis, and regression modeling to identify associations between farm and farmer characteristics, risk perceptions, and risk management responses.Results reveal clear system-level distinctions. Pond farmers, though more experienced, operate at a smaller scale compared to cage farmers. Pond farmers perceive financial and climate risks as most significant and typically employ diversification and subsidy-dependent strategies. Cage farmers, by contrast, are more concerned with operational and market risks and respond through investments in feed quality, infrastructure, and harvest timing. Although cost-saving practices such as homemade feeds are common, they can extend production cycles, increasing vulnerability to theft and labor demands, especially in cage systems.Risk management choices are often shaped by limited information, resource constraints, and behavioral biases, leading to suboptimal outcomes. Cost-efficiency analysis shows that high-cost, high-loss risks, such as water quality deterioration and fish mortality, remain under-managed due to prohibitive mitigation costs, despite their substantial economic consequences.These findings highlight the need for targeted public interventions, such as early-warning systems, price and input quality regulation, tailored extension, and accessible financial tools, to promote preventative, cost-effective risk management. Strengthening these areas can enhance the efficiency and resilience of the aquaculture sector in Kenya and inform policy in similar emerging economies.

title: The Administrative Law of McCarthyism
affiliations: Texas A&M University School of Law

detail.title: The Administrative Law of McCarthyism

publicationDetails.detailsText: Texas A&M University School of Law Legal Studies Research Paper
publicationDetails.journalName: Texas A&M University School of Law Legal Studies Research Paper Series

detail.abstract:
This Article recovers the largely overlooked legal and administrative history of the federal loyalty-security program, and argues that it played a formative role in the development of modern civil service protections and administrative law. During the McCarthy era, the United States Civil Service Commission (CSC), under pressure from Congress, implemented a sweeping loyalty program aimed at rooting out purportedly disloyal federal employees. Though often remembered as a moment of political overreach and civil liberties violations, this Article shows that the loyalty program simultaneously catalyzed a surprising expansion in procedural rights for government workers—both through internal reforms initiated by the CSC and through judicial decisions that extended emerging administrative law doctrines into the domain of federal employment.

Drawing on original archival research, this Article reconstructs how the Loyalty Review Board, housed within the CSC, developed formalized standards for loyalty adjudications, including evidentiary thresholds, rights to notice and counsel, and appellate review. These procedures, while initially limited to loyalty hearings, came to inform broader doctrines governing the removal and discipline of civil servants. In particular, courts began to apply principles such as the Accardi doctrine and the Chenery rule—originally developed for public-facing regulatory action—to disputes between the federal government and its own employees. The result was a nascent body of administrative law that treated personnel decisions not as matters of unfettered executive discretion, but as legal acts subject to procedural constraint.

The Article makes two central claims. First, it argues that civil service law should be understood as a core component of administrative law—not merely a subspecialty of public employment law. Legal rules governing the hiring, discipline, and removal of civil servants serve the same functions as more familiar administrative law doctrines: they mediate interbranch conflict, preventing any one branch from dominating federal policy-making and thus serving deeper separation-of-powers and rule of law values. Second, it argues that the regulation of federal employment not only prevents the aggrandizement of the political branches, but also protects individual rights. In the postwar era, federal jobs functioned as a major form of state-administered benefit, and the procedures surrounding those jobs shaped broader public expectations about fairness, merit, and due process. Those expectations were deeply challenged during the unrest of the McCarthy period, but were ultimately vindicated by the creative adaption of administrative law principles.

These lessons are newly relevant today, as the second Trump administration embarks upon one of the most ambitious attempts to remake the federal civil service in generations, often explicitly seeking to replace merit systems with tests of personal and political loyalty.

title: CBDC Lessons from the Caribbean: Analyzing Central Bank Digital Currency Adoption in Jamaica and The Bahamas
affiliations: Cato Institute

detail.title: CBDC Lessons from the Caribbean: Analyzing Central Bank Digital Currency Adoption in Jamaica and The Bahamas
detail.abstract: Central bank digital currencies (CBDCs) were launched in Jamaica and The Bahamas with ambitious promises: to promote financial inclusion, to stabilize the monetary system, and to foster competition. These same promises have also been made in the United States and abroad as jurisdictions debate whether to launch a CBDC. For example, in the United States, Department of the Treasury official Nellie Liang has said, “A retail CBDC could contribute to a more competitive and innovative payment system; support financial inclusion; and help preserve the singleness of the currency.” Yet several years in, the evidence shows that the CBDCs in both Jamaica and The Bahamas have failed to gain traction with either consumers or businesses. Instead, the CBDCs have become little more than vehicles for government handouts—distributed through limited-time giveaways and incentive programs, with little lasting use. These early experiments provide a cautionary tale for other governments weighing whether to launch a CBDC.

publicationDetails.journalName: IZA Institute of Labor Economics Discussion Paper Series

detail.abstract: We specify the domain in the income distribution that includes the people to whom income transfers will not increase inequality in that income distribution. Inspired by Sens (1973, 1997) characterization of the Gini coefficient as a ratio between a measure of aggregate income-based depression (stress) and aggregate income, we inquire as to whether in the wake of an increase of an income or of incomes in a given income distribution, the Gini coefficient does not increase. To this end, we identify the corresponding safe domain and show that the pivotal value that demarcates this domain can be elicited from a simple linear function of the Gini coefficient itself. Our rule of demarcation provides for policy interventions that seek to increase a particular income or particular incomes while not exacerbating inequality in the income distribution as measured by the Gini coefficient.

detail.abstract: This paper examines a large-scale randomized evaluation of the One Laptop Per Child (OLPC) program in 531 Peruvian rural primary schools. We use administrative data on academic performance and grade progression over 10 years to estimate the long-run effects of increased computer access on (i) school performance over time and (ii) students’ educational trajectories. We find no significant effects on academic performance but some evidence of negative effects on grade progression for treated schools over time. Following students over time, we find no significant effects on primary and secondary completion, academic performance in secondary school, or university enrollment. Survey data indicate that computer access significantly improved students’ computer skills but not their cognitive skills; treated teachers received some training but did not improve their digital skills and showed limited use of technology in classrooms, suggesting the need for additional pedagogical support.

title: Hiring Biases Fostered Under the Code
affiliations: Rutgers University and Liberty University - School of Law

detail.title: Hiring Biases Fostered Under the Code
detail.abstract:
In making employment hiring decisions, employers traditionally consider a multitude of factors, such as candidates’ knowledge, skills, training, education, credentials, and the like. In the post-pandemic landscape, with the growing desire for remote work, employers are now thinking more critically about how employment decisions may affect nexus and related issues for state and local taxes, workers’ compensation, and other compliance burdens. Indeed, carefully weighing the tax and compliance burdens associated with hiring a particular candidate may be outcome-determinative in the selection process.

It’s therefore axiomatic that, everything else being equal, if a particular job candidate would come with lower tax and compliance burdens, that candidate would be more attractive than those who would come with higher burdens. And it may well be that although a particular candidate is stronger in certain areas, any relative marginal increase in strengths is outweighed by the added marginal tax and compliance burden, thereby distorting company-level decision-making and therefore, in the aggregate, the labor market generally.

From an employer’s perspective, one might think that the same tax burden would apply to all job candidates — particularly if they are physically located in the same office or work location. But when it comes to employment taxes, that proposition does not hold true. Nonresident aliens who work in the United States using certain visas, such as F-1 and M-1 visas (student visas), receive a carveout from the definition of employment under the IRC1 such that both they and their employers are exempt from making employment tax payments. The economic implications associated with this exemption are vast and far-reaching. Because of the absence of employment tax obligations, individuals holding these student visas immediately become more attractive job candidates. Consequently, U.S.-based employers have an incentive to hire student visa holders instead of U.S. citizens and residents. Another issue associated with the foregoing labor problem is that, as a result of the student visa employment tax exemption, those dollars are not being paid into the Social Security trust fund, whose asset reserves are projected to be depleted by 2033. 

The public policy question is therefore whether it is prudent to institute tax reform measures that would level the employment playing field between and among U.S. citizens, resident taxpayers, and NRAs and, at the same time, promote Social Security solvency. Our analysis answers that question in the affirmative.

title: Strategic Adaptations to Competition: Supplier Investment Shifts Following Import Tariff Cuts
affiliations: Bentley University - Department of Finance and Rutgers School of Business - Camden

detail.title: Strategic Adaptations to Competition: Supplier Investment Shifts Following Import Tariff Cuts
detail.abstract: This paper examines the effects of increased foreign competition on suppliers’ choice of relationship-specific investments (RSI). Using import tariff reductions as an exogenous shock, we find that in response to heightened competition, suppliers reallocate their investments from long-term R&D expenses to short-term trade credit, suggesting that suppliers balance the need to retain key customers while mitigating increased holdup risks. Cross-sectional analyses show that the decline in R&D spending and increase in trade credit is most pronounced in firms highly vulnerable to holdup risks, whereas firms more dependent on their supply chain tend to offer greater trade credit while maintaining their R&D investment. These findings underscore strategic adjustments made by suppliers to maintain competitiveness and manage risks in the face of shifting market dynamics. We confirm the robustness of these results through placebo tests, entropy balancing, stacked regressions, and alternative tariff cut scenarios.

title: Onsite Oversight: Institutional Site Visits and Stock Return Volatility
affiliations: Central University of Finance and Economics (CUFE) - School of Finance, affiliation not provided to SSRN and Shenzhen University

detail.title: Onsite Oversight: Institutional Site Visits and Stock Return Volatility
detail.abstract: In emerging markets characterized by significant information asymmetry, mitigating firm-level risk is paramount for market stability. While the governance role of institutional investors is known, the impact of their direct, on-the-ground engagement remains underexplored. This study's objective is to investigate how institutional investor site visits, a crucial hands-on governance mechanism, affect stock return volatility. Using a sample of Chinese-listed A-share firms from 2012 to 2022, we find that frequent site visits significantly reduce firm-level stock return volatility. This risk-reduction effect is more pronounced for firms with greater agency problems, poorer ESG performance, and higher expropriation risk. Our analysis, robust to endogeneity concerns, indicates this effect is driven by improved external oversight. We conclude that direct institutional engagement is a vital channel for reducing information asymmetry, enhancing corporate governance, and ultimately promoting market stability by lowering investment risk.

detail.title: Generative AI and the Scope of EU Copyright Law: A Doctrinal Analysis in Light of C-250/25

detail.abstract: This article offers a doctrinal analysis of the copyright implications raised by Like Company v. Google Ireland (C-250/25), the first case to bring generative AI before the CJEU. It examines whether the training and output of systems like Gemini infringe exclusive rights under EU copyright law. We argue that AI model training may involve acts of reproduction under Article 2 of the InfoSoc Directive, while the dissemination of AI-generated outputsespecially through public interfaces-may trigger the right of communication to the public under Article 3. Particular concerns arise when protected content is recognisably reproduced or when AI outputs serve as functional substitutes for original works, thereby affecting the normal exploitation of those works. While not a formal infringement criterion, such functional substitution is relevant in assessing the application of exceptions and compliance with the three-step test. The paper also challenges the applicability of the text and data mining exception to generative uses, highlighting its incompatibility with the limitations imposed by the three-step test. Ultimately, the analysis supports a technologically neutral, rights-based interpretation that safeguards the economic viability of creative production in the algorithmic age.

title: Athens, Rome, and the Political Economy of Ancient Assemblies
affiliations: University of Southern California - Marshall School of Business

detail.title: Athens, Rome, and the Political Economy of Ancient Assemblies
detail.abstract: Citizen assemblies were the core institution of the democracies of the ancient Mediterranean world. Assemblies had the power to make laws and elect magistrates. These assemblies have been widely criticized by both ancient and modern observers for making poor decisions, but the reasons they would have done so are not well understood. This paper develops a public choice model of ancient assemblies to illuminate the challenges they faced and explain why their decisions may not have enjoyed popular support. The model assumes that policy con licts stem from different preferences between urban and rural citizens, and that voting was more costly for rural than urban citizens because of travel costs. In this framework, ancient assemblies faced a structural challenge of preventing urban masses from dominating the much more numerous citizens in the countryside. The model provides a method to quantify the amount of policy distortion compared to perfect majority rule. I analyze different institutions that ancient democracies used to manage the representation problem, in particular, Athens' program to pay citizens to attend, and Rome's use of a unique group voting system.

title: The Lived Experiences of Non-Working Mothers in the Women’S Empowerment Program of a Catholic Higher Education Institution

detail.title: The Lived Experiences of Non-Working Mothers in the Women’S Empowerment Program of a Catholic Higher Education Institution
detail.abstract: This study systematically examines how women’s empowerment programs have changed the current situation of non-working mothers in a Catholic Higher Education Institution. It addresses how empowerment initiatives impact their economic independence, personal growth, and social participation. The research highlights that access to livelihood training, skills development, and supportive community networks significantly improved the mothers’ financial stability, self-confidence, and leadership within their families and communities. It concludes that empowerment programs not only transform the lives of marginalized women but also contribute to broader community development and inclusive growth. The study underscores the role of empowerment initiatives in promoting gender equality and enhancing the visibility of non-working mothers, particularly in areas connected to tourism and sustainable economic opportunities.

title: New Evidence on the Impact of Energy Poverty on Industrial Performance in Africa
affiliations: Université de Bourgogne and United Nations Economic Commission for Africa

detail.title: New Evidence on the Impact of Energy Poverty on Industrial Performance in Africa
detail.abstract: Industrialisation is essential for Africa’s long-term development, offering a pathway to economic diversification, employment generation, and resilience to external shocks. Given the continent’s demographic and structural challenges, transitioning to higher value-added, technologically advanced industries is a necessity. However, energy poverty remains a major obstacle. As energy is critical to all stages of industrial production, the lack of reliable, affordable, and sustainable electricity constrains industrial growth. Against this backdrop, this study analyses the effects of energy poverty on industrial performance across 33 African countries over the period 1996–2020, using the System Generalized Method of Moments (SGMM) approach and a new Index, the Competitive Industrial Performance (CIP). Through a series of robustness checks, the results indicate that reducing energy poverty has a positive and statistically significant impact on industrial performance in Africa. Moreover, this study highlights the mediating role of human capital, financial development, and income level in the relationship between energy poverty and industrial performance. Furthermore, the findings reveal that reducing energy poverty enhances the capacity for industrial development, with significant impacts on the industrial sector and structural transformation. These results re-affirm the importance for African countries to improve the accessibility and availability of energy to support industrialisation and economic development.
